RIEDER: Totally. And the point being, people focus on the 10-year treasury, and I say if we get three percent 10-year, my God, it's all over. The 3-year -- you know, the 10-year treasury, we think, will probably go to three and quarter this year, but we think of more in the second half of the year, but it's not that scary -- we're not talking about historically high rates.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, 2.76 percent is where we are right now, and any time we get close to three percent, this market sells off.

RIEDER: Yes, I don't really understand. It's like, 2.95 is OK, but don't get three.

BARTIROMO: Right.

RIEDER: Yes, I don't really understand that. I mean, there is a difference. By the way, the front-end yield curve is a big difference because it means that now I don't take any risk, I don't have to take 10- year treasury risk. That is a big deal. But listen, if rates move up gradually, then markets will be fine.

BARTIROMO: So, you think there are values in equities right now?

RIEDER: I do, I do. I think.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about that.

RIEDER: So, I think what ends up happening is, you know, people, whether it's tech or tariffs, there is the short-term data that I think spooks people in terms of how much risk. And people have taken a lot of risk in January; people were building a lot of risk. Evaluations in the equity market today are not that bad. I mean, there are places, I would argue, you know, I'm not in, you know, fixed income. But when you think about, you know, somewhere where the financials are, and some of the multiples, and some of these. They're actually pretty attractive today. You know, so some complement: I could buy treasuries in the front end carry well, and then there's parts of the equity market and I could take some risk to build a balanced portfolio.

BARTIROMO: Especially going into the reporting season, which we are about to enter. The first quarter reporting is: we were expecting corporate earnings to be up 16.5 percent for the first quarter.

RIEDER: Not only earnings. I mean, we focus, we look a lot of revenues to get a sense for what is the forward growth. The revenues are going to be pretty substantial. Meaning, you're going to have what we think will be durable earnings. And I'm a big believer of this tax bill which people talk about enough the ability to write off your direct expensing. And I could, some said, company you're seeing capex surge, it means growth will continue to be good, earnings will continue to be good. And by the way, 21 percent tax rate means that these numbers going to look pretty positive for a while.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. I mean, going from a corporate rate of 40 percent -- close to 40 percent to 21 percent is a huge deal. And you think this is going to have legs? It's not just going to be an overnight success, but we're going to see an impact to corporates for a year or two.

RIEDER: I think people underestimate the cash flow benefit for companies, particularly financials, particularly health care, managed care, et cetera. The flow-through because Capex writing off interest, writing off (INAUDIBLE) is a big deal, and I will spur spending. Now, that being said, there's one that I think is a concern. The amount of debt we're putting in the system is a lot.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and treasury is going to have to borrow a trillion dollars this fiscal year to cover government spending, lower tax revenue. How does that impact the bond market?

RIEDER: It's a big deal. By the way, (INAUDIBLE) and then ultimately the equity market. You know, listen, there is some part which have driven short term rates -- worth pumping so many treasury bills. We're going to do bills. We get two years, three years, five years. It's a lot of debt. For the next three years, the trillion dollars of additional net debt that has to be funded by marketplace, it's a lot. It's what will push -- you know, inflation is not scary. It's what is going to push rates moderately higher. You know, what will be key is we're going to absorb that various ways to make money and fixed income, you've got be really careful with how much interest rate exposure you have with this much issuance is going to come out of the market.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you make money and fixed income right now?

RIEDER: So, first of all. I mean, you know holding the front of the -- so then, emerging markets are, you know, people have been blown away. Why would all this volatility? Emerging markets aren't moving around that much. It's because they don't have leverage to use at. And they're giving you substantial yield. So, we like only that -- we like buying a lot of secured assets. So, commercial mortgages, not agencies, carry really well, don't take a log of yield curve for us. You can make in fixed income.

BARTIROMO: Let me get your take on the Libor. The journal is reporting that the race, "Rapid Rise", they're highlighting that. What do you think are the implications of that?

RIEDER: It's huge. I mean it today, it is the financing of the market poise. Some of them has to do with the patriation, it's a short term in Fox. I know that it has to do with the treasury bill, which and set anything done. And then, they're also financing as some of the foreign banks, because the tax bill, some impact to that. It's incredibly important because it's the gearing of how financial system works. It doesn't get focus on enough. Our senses, it'll start to stabilize here. We don't think it's come back a lot, but it will stabilize. And a lot of the pressure is from the village who slaughtered the pressure from the repatriation. We'll shut to stabilize. But people underestimate how big a deal. There's so much important (INAUDIBLE) in the financial system.

BARTIROMO: Rick, thanks so much for your insight.

RIEDER: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: I'll see you on Wall Street this weekend. Rick Rieder of Blackrock. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Technologies got a bid this morning. Tech stocks are higher after the sell-off recently. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching that and what should be boomer opening this morning, Nic.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: I know, Maria, well, this is the last trading days you've been hinting and all the last quarters were so great, there were so much window dressing happening now because they didn't have to do that in all those prior -quarters. I got a note from over at Wedbush, Joe Colina who said as far as tech, the triple Qs were looking to the upside this morning but they were held hostage yesterday. But they expected this move and they're going to be watching the FANG Index, NVidia, Netflix, Facebook, Google, and the triple Qs need to reclaim the 100 days sooner than later. Quick look at some of the details here. So, Facebook in the premarket is up one percent.

Snap is looking higher, Amazon to the downside, Facebook cutting ties with some of the data brokers, this -- those data brokers gather your information for advertisers, they're making all kinds of changes. Before the month, Facebook is down 14 percent, and then Snap is cutting 100 employees. They've been -- it's their latest round of downsizing. Snap over the last 52 weeks, down 30 percent roughly.

And then there is Amazon, and look at the tweet from our president, President Trump, stating his concerns once again about Amazon's -- he's been saying it since the election, that they pay little or no taxes, they use the postal system as their delivery boy. Amazon a bit to the down side this morning. Before the month, it's down five percent, but certainly, we feel the White House steeping in to try and curb the dominant growth that we've been seeing for Amazon. But big picture, tech have been the story of this month. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much. Amazon not catching a bid, stock is down as you just told us, Nic. Joining us to weigh in "VARNEY & COMPANY" host, Stuart Varney. Stu, good to see you.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: You, too, maria.

BARTIROMO: The President says Amazon is putting thousands of retailers out of business and that's just one part of the problem he has with Amazon.

VARNEY: Yes, he's clearly going after them, and that's a fact on taxes, on retailers, et cetera, et cetera.

BARTIROMO: We knew that would come, right, Stu?

VARNEY: I don't know whether it would -- I knew it would come from the President. I'm not surprised by it. After all, The Washington Post which is a principal Trump-hating vehicle is owned by Jeff Bezos, who runs Amazon. So, there is sort of a nasty connection there between the two, so I'm not that surprised, but I think this is all a precursor to a reworking of our antitrust laws. I think that the big tech companies have created quite a few enemies and a lot of concern about their power in all kinds of industries. And I think those concerns are going to come to a head with some kind of antitrust action against one or all of them. What form it takes, I don't know, because you'll have to rework the antitrust laws to take account of the 21st century as opposed to the late 19th century or early 20th century, but I think that's what's coming. And I think that's what's spooking the markets because if you really do apply some form of antitrust law to these giants, they're going to pay a price.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, they're more -- they're more powerful and more influential than they've ever been.

VARNEY: Oh, absolutely so, yes. I mean, look how much of the stock market rally is concentrated in the five tech stocks. It's 40 percent, something like that. Extraordinary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. And tech is 25 percent of the S&P500, right?

MCDOWELL: It's 27.

BARTIROMO: 27 percent. Stu, we'll see you in about 10 minutes.

VARNEY: Yes, you will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, excitement revs up for the New York auto show. We've got a sneak peek at the coolest wheels hitting the road. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. NissanRenault looking to make their marriage official. The automakers have had an alliance for two decades and reports say now they may officially merge. This comes, as car companies show off their new models at this year's New York auto show. That's where we find foxnews.com Automotive Editor, Gary Gastelu. Gary, good morning to you.

GARY GASTELU, FOXNEWS.COM AUTOMOTIVE EDITOR: How you doing, Maria? You know, if you've been in the mall parking lot lately, you may not be surprised that pretty much all the cars here that are being revealed are SUVs. There's a new Subaru Forester, new Toyota RAV4 which was the best- selling vehicle in America last year that's not a pickup. And the showstopper was a pickup based on an SUV, it's the new Volkswagen Atlas Tanoak concept. And this is one that they're going to be thinking about making in Tennessee if enough people like it. More car-like than a pickup truck is going to be, it's more for lifestyle buyers, but if enough people raise their hand, they are going to go ahead and make this car because there's definitely a market for this sort of thing. And based on the attention it's been getting here, it's certainly a big hit.

You know, it's almost more unusual to see a car at a car show these days, and I've got the most unusual car at this show right now. It's the Rimac Concept Two. This is an all-electric super car that's made in Croatia of all places. It has 2,000 horsepower, which means it's about three times more powerful than the most powerful Teslas, it had a top speed of 258 miles an hour, will be the quickest car in the world when it goes on sale. And it can drive itself, at least the company says it can. We'll see about that. It is the Concept Two. They've made the Concept One which they have already sold. So, this one is definitely the real thing, 150 of them for about a million dollars a pop.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That is -- you know, that is funny though that you would say that. It's hard to see a car at a car show but that certainly a hot wheels there. But the trend has once again been big.

GASTELU: Absolutely, Cadillac has got the new XTS, it's the Lincoln Aviator which is probably going to be one of its best-selling vehicles coming up soon. You know, the fuel economy is better, they ride better, people are moving up into the bigger vehicles. And there's no stopping that right now from what the people here are saying.

BARTIROMO: Gary, thanks so much. Gary Gastelu is up the New York auto show. We're going to take a break, then we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from our all-star panel right now. Lindsey Bell?

BELL: That's 16-1/2 percent cue on earnings numbers we're talking about. We need to remember this is the first quarter that we're going to have tax reform in those numbers. We'll see is it enough, did they move the numbers enough or not?

BARTIROMO: Yes. And then we're going to watch guidance, obviously. We're expecting 18 percent growth in earnings for 2018. Steve Forbes?

FORBES: We should have relief that we haven't had a trade war. That South Korean agreement, not great but we didn't blow it up. Big thing, next thing we look at is NAFTA. We get the same kind of agreement there. Wipe your brow. Please stake a big one.

BARTIROMO: Not going to happen before the Mexican elections.

FORBES: That's going to be huge and who's going to win that in Mexico? We could have a bad actor there, another (INAUDIBLE) type.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right, the lefty guy. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: So, instead of going on Facebook and liking some Hillary Clinton meme that your mother posts, call her on the phone and tell her you love her. I think that -- maybe this is a warning sign that the relationships that we build and develop online are not the healthiest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, a good point. Great panel, everybody. Thanks for being here. Wishing everybody at their happy Easter. Dagen's got you covered tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stu, take it away.

END

urn:contentItem:5W46-K6K1-DY0W-433G-00000-00Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of Directors2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRoseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of DirectorsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, thank you so much. Happy Thursday to you, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast: Technology tumbling, shares of several big tech names fell yet again yesterday amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are now in bear market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, Amazon all in correction territory. Take a look at those numbers, the slide coming amid fears of a regulatory crackdown following Facebook's personal data scandal. Apple's CEO Tim Cook, slams Facebook.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: We're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. Privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decline weighed on the major averages once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years. We are ending the month, ending the quarter for business this week, today, actually. Dow Industrials down nine points yesterday. S&P500 down seven, and the NASDAQ down almost 60, almost one percent lower in yesterday's trade.

Let's check futures right now, we're looking at a balance at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up about 90 points, that's one- third of one percent. S&P500 up half of percent with the 12-point moving. And the NASDAQ is up almost one percent bouncing after yesterday's decline of 55 points, right now. In Europe stocks are also higher. Take a look, the major indices higher across the board with the DAX Index in Germany up one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. Best performer there as you see, up KOSPI Index and the Shanghai Composite in China. Point of a quarter percent.

White House shake up once again now. Veterans Affairs, Secretary David Shulkin is out. President Trump has nominated White House position, Admiral Ronny Jackson to take over the position. The details on Shulkin's departure, coming up right here.

Collusion in the capital newly uncovered checks show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department along with democratic leadership over the Russia investigation. The shocking revelations coming up this morning.

And Roseanne storms back despite criticism from the left. The sitcom delivers a staggering 18 million viewers in its return debut. More as the show story gets a congratulatory call from the commander-in-chief.

Plus, Blue Moon going green. The company's creator looks to brew up a new business with marijuana infused beer. We will tap in to that story, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Networks, Dagen McDowell. Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is here and CFRA Investment strategist, Lindsey Bell joining us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us, Steve.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Steve has seen it all in terms of investing, in terms of politics. So, again, nobody better to have on the program this morning.

BARTIROMO: That's true. What's the most important to you this morning? What are you looking at? Markets, obviously under pressure.

FORBES: What you want to see is what's going to be the reaction to these tech companies to the assault. They did not see it coming, not more than Microsoft 20 years ago so the intrusive coming after them. Right now, Facebook has got the biggest problem because Zuckerberg has been very poor in his response. He should've laid out. They should've had better auditing, better follow-up to make sure their rules were followed. But you know, we all knew, when we go on those things, we get those things free, but They're going to use our data to sell us (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: How did they not see that coming, Dagen? I mean --

MCDOWELL: I think Mark Zuckerberg needs to start setting his alarm for 2:00 a.m. West Coast time and watching "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". Because we've been talking about this literally for years. I have said verbatim on this program, if you don't start typing up your business in the management of it and it wasn't just the privacy data. It was like, rolling out, I've said the Facebook live video, policing terrorists on your social network. You're asking for regulators to walk in the front door. And it's not going to be (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And you also alienated conservatives by discriminating with the algorithms on Facebook and other places. Conservative websites, dumb thing to do.

BARTIROMO: That's -- and that happened throughout the election, we know that.

FORBES: Yes, it did.

BARTIROMO: You know, googling Hillary Clinton to get one set of stories. You Google Donald Trump, you get a whole different set of stories.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and treasury is going to have to borrow a trillion dollars this fiscal year to cover government spending, lower tax revenue. How does that impact the bond market?

RIEDER: It's a big deal. By the way, (INAUDIBLE) and then ultimately the equity market. You know, listen, there is some part which have driven short term rates -- worth pumping so many treasury bills. We're going to do bills. We get two years, three years, five years. It's a lot of debt. For the next three years, the trillion dollars of additional net debt that has to be funded by marketplace, it's a lot. It's what will push -- you know, inflation is not scary. It's what is going to push rates moderately higher. You know, what will be key is we're going to absorb that various ways to make money and fixed income, you've got be really careful with how much interest rate exposure you have with this much issuance is going to come out of the market.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you make money and fixed income right now?

RIEDER: So, first of all. I mean, you know holding the front of the -- so then, emerging markets are, you know, people have been blown away. Why would all this volatility? Emerging markets aren't moving around that much. It's because they don't have leverage to use at. And they're giving you substantial yield. So, we like only that -- we like buying a lot of secured assets. So, commercial mortgages, not agencies, carry really well, don't take a log of yield curve for us. You can make in fixed income.

BARTIROMO: Let me get your take on the Libor. The journal is reporting that the race, "Rapid Rise", they're highlighting that. What do you think are the implications of that?

RIEDER: It's huge. I mean it today, it is the financing of the market poise. Some of them has to do with the patriation, it's a short term in Fox. I know that it has to do with the treasury bill, which and set anything done. And then, they're also financing as some of the foreign banks, because the tax bill, some impact to that. It's incredibly important because it's the gearing of how financial system works. It doesn't get focus on enough. Our senses, it'll start to stabilize here. We don't think it's come back a lot, but it will stabilize. And a lot of the pressure is from the village who slaughtered the pressure from the repatriation. We'll shut to stabilize. But people underestimate how big a deal. There's so much important (INAUDIBLE) in the financial system.

BARTIROMO: Rick, thanks so much for your insight.

RIEDER: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: I'll see you on Wall Street this weekend. Rick Rieder of Blackrock. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Technologies got a bid this morning. Tech stocks are higher after the sell-off recently. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching that and what should be boomer opening this morning, Nic.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: I know, Maria, well, this is the last trading days you've been hinting and all the last quarters were so great, there were so much window dressing happening now because they didn't have to do that in all those prior -quarters. I got a note from over at Wedbush, Joe Colina who said as far as tech, the triple Qs were looking to the upside this morning but they were held hostage yesterday. But they expected this move and they're going to be watching the FANG Index, NVidia, Netflix, Facebook, Google, and the triple Qs need to reclaim the 100 days sooner than later. Quick look at some of the details here. So, Facebook in the premarket is up one percent.

Snap is looking higher, Amazon to the downside, Facebook cutting ties with some of the data brokers, this -- those data brokers gather your information for advertisers, they're making all kinds of changes. Before the month, Facebook is down 14 percent, and then Snap is cutting 100 employees. They've been -- it's their latest round of downsizing. Snap over the last 52 weeks, down 30 percent roughly.

And then there is Amazon, and look at the tweet from our president, President Trump, stating his concerns once again about Amazon's -- he's been saying it since the election, that they pay little or no taxes, they use the postal system as their delivery boy. Amazon a bit to the down side this morning. Before the month, it's down five percent, but certainly, we feel the White House steeping in to try and curb the dominant growth that we've been seeing for Amazon. But big picture, tech have been the story of this month. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much. Amazon not catching a bid, stock is down as you just told us, Nic. Joining us to weigh in "VARNEY & COMPANY" host, Stuart Varney. Stu, good to see you.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: You, too, maria.

BARTIROMO: The President says Amazon is putting thousands of retailers out of business and that's just one part of the problem he has with Amazon.

VARNEY: Yes, he's clearly going after them, and that's a fact on taxes, on retailers, et cetera, et cetera.

BARTIROMO: We knew that would come, right, Stu?

VARNEY: I don't know whether it would -- I knew it would come from the President. I'm not surprised by it. After all, The Washington Post which is a principal Trump-hating vehicle is owned by Jeff Bezos, who runs Amazon. So, there is sort of a nasty connection there between the two, so I'm not that surprised, but I think this is all a precursor to a reworking of our antitrust laws. I think that the big tech companies have created quite a few enemies and a lot of concern about their power in all kinds of industries. And I think those concerns are going to come to a head with some kind of antitrust action against one or all of them. What form it takes, I don't know, because you'll have to rework the antitrust laws to take account of the 21st century as opposed to the late 19th century or early 20th century, but I think that's what's coming. And I think that's what's spooking the markets because if you really do apply some form of antitrust law to these giants, they're going to pay a price.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, they're more -- they're more powerful and more influential than they've ever been.

VARNEY: Oh, absolutely so, yes. I mean, look how much of the stock market rally is concentrated in the five tech stocks. It's 40 percent, something like that. Extraordinary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. And tech is 25 percent of the S&P500, right?

MCDOWELL: It's 27.

BARTIROMO: 27 percent. Stu, we'll see you in about 10 minutes.

VARNEY: Yes, you will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, excitement revs up for the New York auto show. We've got a sneak peek at the coolest wheels hitting the road. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. NissanRenault looking to make their marriage official. The automakers have had an alliance for two decades and reports say now they may officially merge. This comes, as car companies show off their new models at this year's New York auto show. That's where we find foxnews.com Automotive Editor, Gary Gastelu. Gary, good morning to you.

GARY GASTELU, FOXNEWS.COM AUTOMOTIVE EDITOR: How you doing, Maria? You know, if you've been in the mall parking lot lately, you may not be surprised that pretty much all the cars here that are being revealed are SUVs. There's a new Subaru Forester, new Toyota RAV4 which was the best- selling vehicle in America last year that's not a pickup. And the showstopper was a pickup based on an SUV, it's the new Volkswagen Atlas Tanoak concept. And this is one that they're going to be thinking about making in Tennessee if enough people like it. More car-like than a pickup truck is going to be, it's more for lifestyle buyers, but if enough people raise their hand, they are going to go ahead and make this car because there's definitely a market for this sort of thing. And based on the attention it's been getting here, it's certainly a big hit.

You know, it's almost more unusual to see a car at a car show these days, and I've got the most unusual car at this show right now. It's the Rimac Concept Two. This is an all-electric super car that's made in Croatia of all places. It has 2,000 horsepower, which means it's about three times more powerful than the most powerful Teslas, it had a top speed of 258 miles an hour, will be the quickest car in the world when it goes on sale. And it can drive itself, at least the company says it can. We'll see about that. It is the Concept Two. They've made the Concept One which they have already sold. So, this one is definitely the real thing, 150 of them for about a million dollars a pop.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That is -- you know, that is funny though that you would say that. It's hard to see a car at a car show but that certainly a hot wheels there. But the trend has once again been big.

GASTELU: Absolutely, Cadillac has got the new XTS, it's the Lincoln Aviator which is probably going to be one of its best-selling vehicles coming up soon. You know, the fuel economy is better, they ride better, people are moving up into the bigger vehicles. And there's no stopping that right now from what the people here are saying.

BARTIROMO: Gary, thanks so much. Gary Gastelu is up the New York auto show. We're going to take a break, then we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from our all-star panel right now. Lindsey Bell?

BELL: That's 16-1/2 percent cue on earnings numbers we're talking about. We need to remember this is the first quarter that we're going to have tax reform in those numbers. We'll see is it enough, did they move the numbers enough or not?

BARTIROMO: Yes. And then we're going to watch guidance, obviously. We're expecting 18 percent growth in earnings for 2018. Steve Forbes?

FORBES: We should have relief that we haven't had a trade war. That South Korean agreement, not great but we didn't blow it up. Big thing, next thing we look at is NAFTA. We get the same kind of agreement there. Wipe your brow. Please stake a big one.

BARTIROMO: Not going to happen before the Mexican elections.

FORBES: That's going to be huge and who's going to win that in Mexico? We could have a bad actor there, another (INAUDIBLE) type.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right, the lefty guy. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: So, instead of going on Facebook and liking some Hillary Clinton meme that your mother posts, call her on the phone and tell her you love her. I think that -- maybe this is a warning sign that the relationships that we build and develop online are not the healthiest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, a good point. Great panel, everybody. Thanks for being here. Wishing everybody at their happy Easter. Dagen's got you covered tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stu, take it away.

END

urn:contentItem:5W46-K6K1-DY0W-433H-00000-00Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of Directors2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRoseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of DirectorsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, thank you so much. Happy Thursday to you, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast: Technology tumbling, shares of several big tech names fell yet again yesterday amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are now in bear market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, Amazon all in correction territory. Take a look at those numbers, the slide coming amid fears of a regulatory crackdown following Facebook's personal data scandal. Apple's CEO Tim Cook, slams Facebook.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: We're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. Privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decline weighed on the major averages once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years. We are ending the month, ending the quarter for business this week, today, actually. Dow Industrials down nine points yesterday. S&P500 down seven, and the NASDAQ down almost 60, almost one percent lower in yesterday's trade.

Let's check futures right now, we're looking at a balance at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up about 90 points, that's one- third of one percent. S&P500 up half of percent with the 12-point moving. And the NASDAQ is up almost one percent bouncing after yesterday's decline of 55 points, right now. In Europe stocks are also higher. Take a look, the major indices higher across the board with the DAX Index in Germany up one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. Best performer there as you see, up KOSPI Index and the Shanghai Composite in China. Point of a quarter percent.

White House shake up once again now. Veterans Affairs, Secretary David Shulkin is out. President Trump has nominated White House position, Admiral Ronny Jackson to take over the position. The details on Shulkin's departure, coming up right here.

Collusion in the capital newly uncovered checks show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department along with democratic leadership over the Russia investigation. The shocking revelations coming up this morning.

And Roseanne storms back despite criticism from the left. The sitcom delivers a staggering 18 million viewers in its return debut. More as the show story gets a congratulatory call from the commander-in-chief.

Plus, Blue Moon going green. The company's creator looks to brew up a new business with marijuana infused beer. We will tap in to that story, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Networks, Dagen McDowell. Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is here and CFRA Investment strategist, Lindsey Bell joining us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us, Steve.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Steve has seen it all in terms of investing, in terms of politics. So, again, nobody better to have on the program this morning.

BARTIROMO: That's true. What's the most important to you this morning? What are you looking at? Markets, obviously under pressure.

FORBES: What you want to see is what's going to be the reaction to these tech companies to the assault. They did not see it coming, not more than Microsoft 20 years ago so the intrusive coming after them. Right now, Facebook has got the biggest problem because Zuckerberg has been very poor in his response. He should've laid out. They should've had better auditing, better follow-up to make sure their rules were followed. But you know, we all knew, when we go on those things, we get those things free, but They're going to use our data to sell us (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: How did they not see that coming, Dagen? I mean --

MCDOWELL: I think Mark Zuckerberg needs to start setting his alarm for 2:00 a.m. West Coast time and watching "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". Because we've been talking about this literally for years. I have said verbatim on this program, if you don't start typing up your business in the management of it and it wasn't just the privacy data. It was like, rolling out, I've said the Facebook live video, policing terrorists on your social network. You're asking for regulators to walk in the front door. And it's not going to be (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And you also alienated conservatives by discriminating with the algorithms on Facebook and other places. Conservative websites, dumb thing to do.

BARTIROMO: That's -- and that happened throughout the election, we know that.

FORBES: Yes, it did.

BARTIROMO: You know, googling Hillary Clinton to get one set of stories. You Google Donald Trump, you get a whole different set of stories.

BELL: What I just noticed, was the Nasdaq was up to most this morning, you know, just under one percentage point. So, maybe this means the bleeding could be done for the tech sector. We saw Facebook and Google who got had the most in this privacy concern and they were flat yesterday.

BARTIROMO: That's right yesterday -- this morning we'll see how investors react. Joining the conversation, White House National Trade Council Director Peter Navarro is with us this morning. Former Reagan Budget Director, David Stockman is here. Great America PAC Chairman and former Reagan Chief White House Political Adviser, Ed Rollins joins us. And the CIO of Blackrock Global CIO with fixed income Rick Rieder is with us as well. We got a big show this morning. So, do stay with us.

We kick it off right here with technology stocks weighing on Wall Street. U.S. markets closed lower yesterday after worries set in about increased regulatory oversight. They slammed chairs at big tech companies, yesterday. Amazon among the day's worst performers losing better than four percent. After Axios reported that President Trump wants to go after Amazon on taxes or antitrust grounds. Facebook shares have fallen 14 percent this month but rose slightly yesterday at the close after the social network announced it would shut down a third-party ad targeting tool.

Meanwhile, Apple CEO Tim Cook added his voice to the scores of criticisms over Facebook's data privacy practices. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOK: The truth is we could make a ton of money if we monetized our customer, if our customer was our product, we could make a ton of money. We've elected not to do that. We care about the user experience. And we're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. I think it's -- privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting to hear Apple talk about Facebook that way, Lindsey and it really did hit a whole slack of tech companies yesterday.

BELL: It really did, and you know what, it is concerning because the tech sector really has been the bellwether for the stock market for the last year plus. So, we're going to be really watching first-quarter earnings. This is a sector though that I have to remind people, you know, the fundamentals really are intact for the tech sector. In the last six quarters you saw technology, sector companies beat earnings estimates by almost eight percentage point. That's a huge beat. Usually S&P 500 companies get four percent beat.

BARTIROMO: But does this cut into that growth? I mean, does the reason to only stops change with the bigger regulatory bite?

BELL: I mean, yes, it's definitely going to be a concern, but I do think that when you look at the market overall, you look at the 11 sectors and the S&P 500, it's going to be hard to find growth like you've seen here. And sure, Amazon and Facebook are huge components of that, but we'll see how that comes out.

BARTIROMO: That's quite a weigh, you're still looking at 16 percent growth? In earnings for the first quarter?

BELL: 18.6 percent.

BARTIROMO: Which actually exact the year for the quarter?

BELL: Sorry that's for the quarter, for the first -- for the year -- the first-quarter we're looking at 16.5 percent. That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Right, 16.5 percent for the first quarter. Steve, let me ask you about Amazon. Because once the President got in place. We were all speculating what would happen with Amazon, I mean, we know how the "Washington Post" has treated this president throughout his presidency. Finally, there is this. Blue Moon Beer is adding a little green. The brewery company is launching three marijuana infused beers. They're alcohol free, but again, they're filled marijuana. They're going to be served chilled only available in Colorado. They're going to starts that this fall. Company says, they will begin with light beer, a wheat beer, and a stout beer just to start. Shares of Blue Moon's parent company, Molson Coors, down about eight percent so far, this year. Pot-infused beer, Maria. Those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and, you know, marijuana is legal in Colorado. Here's a good tweet on that Susan Rice story. Dagen, what do you think about Susan Rice joining the board of Netflix? Here's a tweet from Karen Nelson, she says: "Big mistake, Netflix," and then a picture of Susan Rice, "I spy." Big mistake, I spy. I don't know, she unmasked. She did all that unmasking, right?

MCDOWELL: And then, she lied about the Benghazi attacks that she went on national television and lied to the American people and lied to the families about why those individuals were killed. Oh, I remember it was a video.

BARTIROMO: It was a video. And it happens to be September 11th, but it was a video.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

BARTIROMO: Not a terrorist attack. But, I don't know, but her experience to go on the board of Netflix.

MCDOWELL: It's a love fest, baby. Come on! A lot of documentaries that they have on there and I watch a lot of them, they're very, very left- leaning.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. OK.

BELL: This isn't going to help them in the current regulatory environment, I don't think. Regulatory is currently in Washington.

BARTIROMO: While this focuses on a bigger bite from Washington, you see.

FORBES: Consider the reception of Roseanne and what the hasting is doing with Netflix bringing on these far left-wing people is going to hurt. And what does he expect to get? He loves crony capitalism. He loves regulation and helps Netflix. It's so called net neutrality debate which is regulating the Internet to help the big guys. What's his game plan on this? What does think he's going to get out of it?

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's a very good point.

FORBES: It alienates half the country. You can have your opinions and voice them. But, you've got a company that you're supposed to be steward of, come on.

BARTIROMO: Especially since we just saw the success of Roseann, really important to put that out. We're going to take a break. When we come back, pulling on the apron strings. Blue Apron seems to be in trouble after its flashy IPO last year. We're taking a look at what the future holds for the meal kit company next. And then, of course, there's Tesla, stay with us on that.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Investors are hoping meal kit company, Blue Apron, can cook something up as the stocks lived again. Lauren Simonetti with all the details now, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN REPORTER: It's an ugly tart, Maria. I mean, this is the stock that in June of last year, IPO-ed a $10.00 a share. It's at a $1.88. We were talking at one point of like $2 billion value slashed to $360 million. So, it's certainly running on fumes. Mismanagement by the company, over spending. Competition not only with the -- look at the char -- not only the likes of Amazon but also with other meal preparation kit companies like Hello Fresh, which is bigger, believe it or not, than Blue Apron. So, you know, if they're running on fumes, and someone to come in to buy them and who should that person be? Rumors say Costco could be a potential buyer. But is this the state of the IPO market this year? Not necessarily the case. In fact, Renaissance IPO is out with some new numbers for the first quarter which ends today. We've seen 43 IPOs raising $15.6 billion. This is being led mostly by tech and by technology companies.

Speaking of tech, Dropbox, Unicorn, they IPO-ed on Friday. I remember Friday because that was the day when the big tech companies like Facebook and Amazon tumbled three percent each. And you have Dropbox IPO-ing on that day, shares popping 36 percent. And look at this, they IPO-ed at 21, not even a week ago, and they're trading in the premarket at $31.00 a share. So, so far so good. Tuesday, we hear from Spotify. So, we'll see how IPO market holds up. Do you guys know Yeti, by the way? The Yeti Coolers.

MCDOWELL: It's a cooler. They look cool. It's a cooler.

SIMONETTI: Well, I'm glad you say it like that because they dropped their plans; they withdrew their listing. And speculation is, it could have something to do with the steel and aluminum tariffs, because obviously that's what's in their tumblers, and their thermoses, and coolers or they don't want to go the way of, you know, GoPro -- you have a great premium product.

MCDOWELL: As my father told me, I know those Yeti Coolers look real cool hanging off the back of somebody's pickup truck. But he said, they're a bear to get into. And he said, I can't get my bud quick enough. That's how he --

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: We had long family discussions at the dinner table about the flaws in Yeti Coolers.

SIMONETTI: A premium product, not that many. They don't -- I guess they don't want to go the way of GoPro, for instance, but nonetheless, is bags questions: what is the state on IPO market right after a good first quarter?

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting to see such a strong quarter in the first quarter ever while markets were volatile. Markets were actually down for the first quarter. But the IPOs did well. Lauren, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Could be the worst margin in 17 years.

BARTIROMO: Lauren Simonetti, we'll follow it. Still ahead, as questions mount about your privacy on Facebook, we've got the sever Genie to change ASAP to protect yourself. That's next hour right here in MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast: trouble for technology. Shares of several big tech companies under pressure --

urn:contentItem:5S09-SBD1-JB20-G2BF-00000-00Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of Directors2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Steve Forbes, Amy TarkanianNEWSFinancial032901cb.231Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of DirectorsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Lea Gabrielle, Lauren Simonetti

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, thank you so much. Happy Thursday to you, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast: Technology tumbling, shares of several big tech names fell yet again yesterday amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are now in bear market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, Amazon all in correction territory. Take a look at those numbers, the slide coming amid fears of a regulatory crackdown following Facebook's personal data scandal. Apple's CEO Tim Cook, slams Facebook.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: We're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. Privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decline weighed on the major averages once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years. We are ending the month, ending the quarter for business this week, today, actually. Dow Industrials down nine points yesterday. S&P500 down seven, and the NASDAQ down almost 60, almost one percent lower in yesterday's trade.

Let's check futures right now, we're looking at a balance at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up about 90 points, that's one- third of one percent. S&P500 up half of percent with the 12-point moving. And the NASDAQ is up almost one percent bouncing after yesterday's decline of 55 points, right now. In Europe stocks are also higher. Take a look, the major indices higher across the board with the DAX Index in Germany up one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. Best performer there as you see, up KOSPI Index and the Shanghai Composite in China. Point of a quarter percent.

White House shake up once again now. Veterans Affairs, Secretary David Shulkin is out. President Trump has nominated White House position, Admiral Ronny Jackson to take over the position. The details on Shulkin's departure, coming up right here.

Collusion in the capital newly uncovered checks show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department along with democratic leadership over the Russia investigation. The shocking revelations coming up this morning.

And Roseanne storms back despite criticism from the left. The sitcom delivers a staggering 18 million viewers in its return debut. More as the show story gets a congratulatory call from the commander-in-chief.

Plus, Blue Moon going green. The company's creator looks to brew up a new business with marijuana infused beer. We will tap in to that story, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Networks, Dagen McDowell. Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is here and CFRA Investment strategist, Lindsey Bell joining us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us, Steve.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Steve has seen it all in terms of investing, in terms of politics. So, again, nobody better to have on the program this morning.

BARTIROMO: That's true. What's the most important to you this morning? What are you looking at? Markets, obviously under pressure.

FORBES: What you want to see is what's going to be the reaction to these tech companies to the assault. They did not see it coming, not more than Microsoft 20 years ago so the intrusive coming after them. Right now, Facebook has got the biggest problem because Zuckerberg has been very poor in his response. He should've laid out. They should've had better auditing, better follow-up to make sure their rules were followed. But you know, we all knew, when we go on those things, we get those things free, but They're going to use our data to sell us (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: How did they not see that coming, Dagen? I mean --

MCDOWELL: I think Mark Zuckerberg needs to start setting his alarm for 2:00 a.m. West Coast time and watching "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". Because we've been talking about this literally for years. I have said verbatim on this program, if you don't start typing up your business in the management of it and it wasn't just the privacy data. It was like, rolling out, I've said the Facebook live video, policing terrorists on your social network. You're asking for regulators to walk in the front door. And it's not going to be (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And you also alienated conservatives by discriminating with the algorithms on Facebook and other places. Conservative websites, dumb thing to do.

BARTIROMO: That's -- and that happened throughout the election, we know that.

FORBES: Yes, it did.

BARTIROMO: You know, googling Hillary Clinton to get one set of stories. You Google Donald Trump, you get a whole different set of stories.

BELL: What I just noticed, was the Nasdaq was up to most this morning, you know, just under one percentage point. So, maybe this means the bleeding could be done for the tech sector. We saw Facebook and Google who got had the most in this privacy concern and they were flat yesterday.

BARTIROMO: That's right yesterday -- this morning we'll see how investors react. Joining the conversation, White House National Trade Council Director Peter Navarro is with us this morning. Former Reagan Budget Director, David Stockman is here. Great America PAC Chairman and former Reagan Chief White House Political Adviser, Ed Rollins joins us. And the CIO of Blackrock Global CIO with fixed income Rick Rieder is with us as well. We got a big show this morning. So, do stay with us.

We kick it off right here with technology stocks weighing on Wall Street. U.S. markets closed lower yesterday after worries set in about increased regulatory oversight. They slammed chairs at big tech companies, yesterday. Amazon among the day's worst performers losing better than four percent. After Axios reported that President Trump wants to go after Amazon on taxes or antitrust grounds. Facebook shares have fallen 14 percent this month but rose slightly yesterday at the close after the social network announced it would shut down a third-party ad targeting tool.

Meanwhile, Apple CEO Tim Cook added his voice to the scores of criticisms over Facebook's data privacy practices. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOK: The truth is we could make a ton of money if we monetized our customer, if our customer was our product, we could make a ton of money. We've elected not to do that. We care about the user experience. And we're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. I think it's -- privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting to hear Apple talk about Facebook that way, Lindsey and it really did hit a whole slack of tech companies yesterday.

BELL: It really did, and you know what, it is concerning because the tech sector really has been the bellwether for the stock market for the last year plus. So, we're going to be really watching first-quarter earnings. This is a sector though that I have to remind people, you know, the fundamentals really are intact for the tech sector. In the last six quarters you saw technology, sector companies beat earnings estimates by almost eight percentage point. That's a huge beat. Usually S&P 500 companies get four percent beat.

BARTIROMO: But does this cut into that growth? I mean, does the reason to only stops change with the bigger regulatory bite?

BELL: I mean, yes, it's definitely going to be a concern, but I do think that when you look at the market overall, you look at the 11 sectors and the S&P 500, it's going to be hard to find growth like you've seen here. And sure, Amazon and Facebook are huge components of that, but we'll see how that comes out.

BARTIROMO: That's quite a weigh, you're still looking at 16 percent growth? In earnings for the first quarter?

BELL: 18.6 percent.

BARTIROMO: Which actually exact the year for the quarter?

BELL: Sorry that's for the quarter, for the first -- for the year -- the first-quarter we're looking at 16.5 percent. That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Right, 16.5 percent for the first quarter. Steve, let me ask you about Amazon. Because once the President got in place. We were all speculating what would happen with Amazon, I mean, we know how the "Washington Post" has treated this president throughout his presidency. So, they were speculation that maybe he would want to go after Amazon. And then you look at the size of the company and the number of businesses that Amazon is in, and you do question whether or not it is getting too big. What are your thoughts on the White House? I mean, it's pushing back, by the way, on the Axios report that the President may target Amazon on tax or antitrust ground. This is what we heard yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president has said many times before he's always looking to create a level playing field for all businesses and this is no different. He's going to always look at different ways, but there aren't any specific policies on the table at this time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Steve, your thoughts.

FORBES: Mark those words, at this time. That tells you, denial, denial, denial. And what you see here is that I think, basis book the "Washington Post," because he wanted to do it. But he thought there by political protection in Washington. He didn't realize it's going to make him a target. With the Washington Post and said Donald Trump's the greatest thing since George Washington, I think you'd see a little bit of a different attitude. In terms of Amazon, free markets will work in bringing that company down just as it does with any other company over time. I'm old enough remember G.M. when that was the big bad company. IBM when that was a big tech company. Microsoft's going to take over the world. Wal- Mart was going to take over the world, now struggling. So, let the free markets play out. Well, it's amazing that Amazon has successful it's been. Jeff Bezos, by the way uses teams internally to try to keep this company fresh and on the cutting edge.

BARTIROMO: And it's hard to compete with a company that doesn't mind losing a lot of money quarter after quarter.

FORBES: Well, you see this is another lesson for Wall Street from Amazon. If you step down the terms on what you're going do your business, people cut you slack. Just like drug companies, they're always going to take 10 or 12 years to bring something to market. Amazon you know what they're doing, trying to build up volume successfully. But they make enough money to show they're not just losing money. They know how to make money if they want to do it.

MCDOWELL: Facebook largely though, I think that maybe you start to get a division in this companies that how people analyze them. Because I don't think you can value those earnings with so many question marks about Facebook's future. And I'm not talking about the regulators. I am talking about individuals who finally are waking up to abuse of their personal information and how for more than a decade Facebook hasn't given a flying flip about really protecting it and really lying to their users about what they were doing with it or, and not being upfront about privacy protections. And temple does have a line to stand on. Because these are the principles that Steve Jobs put in place from very early on it Apple. So, I think that you don't know how many users will leave, how much growth will slow at Facebook, how the time spent on the platform might shrink and how that will ultimately affect the advertising dollars that flow the Facebook. Because Facebook is raining in, (INAUDIBLE) one finger doing the limiting the information they share with data broker. So, I think, when you try to come up with a valuation on Facebook at this point, that (INAUDIBLE) is a very big question mark.

BELL: So, I think there's a huge amount of uncertainty around Facebook at this given time. And the fourth quarter we saw daily active users start to decline. And this (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And in this country, yes.

BELL: And in this country their biggest market. So, expect to see more of that in the first quarter, especially after this --

FORBES: Although you have to say Tim Cook (INAUDIBLE) could be in his position because he sells product. Facebook is just selling the experience. Not a hard product. And Facebook's motto is now under threat. And their going to have be more of an information sight.

MCDOWELL: Facebook is an advertising --

Speaking of tech, Dropbox, Unicorn, they IPO-ed on Friday. I remember Friday because that was the day when the big tech companies like Facebook and Amazon tumbled three percent each. And you have Dropbox IPO-ing on that day, shares popping 36 percent. And look at this, they IPO-ed at 21, not even a week ago, and they're trading in the premarket at $31.00 a share. So, so far so good. Tuesday, we hear from Spotify. So, we'll see how IPO market holds up. Do you guys know Yeti, by the way? The Yeti Coolers.

MCDOWELL: It's a cooler. They look cool. It's a cooler.

SIMONETTI: Well, I'm glad you say it like that because they dropped their plans; they withdrew their listing. And speculation is, it could have something to do with the steel and aluminum tariffs, because obviously that's what's in their tumblers, and their thermoses, and coolers or they don't want to go the way of, you know, GoPro -- you have a great premium product.

MCDOWELL: As my father told me, I know those Yeti Coolers look real cool hanging off the back of somebody's pickup truck. But he said, they're a bear to get into. And he said, I can't get my bud quick enough. That's how he --

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: We had long family discussions at the dinner table about the flaws in Yeti Coolers.

SIMONETTI: A premium product, not that many. They don't -- I guess they don't want to go the way of GoPro, for instance, but nonetheless, is bags questions: what is the state on IPO market right after a good first quarter?

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting to see such a strong quarter in the first quarter ever while markets were volatile. Markets were actually down for the first quarter. But the IPOs did well. Lauren, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Could be the worst margin in 17 years.

BARTIROMO: Lauren Simonetti, we'll follow it. Still ahead, as questions mount about your privacy on Facebook, we've got the sever Genie to change ASAP to protect yourself. That's next hour right here in MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast: trouble for technology. Shares of several big tech companies under pressure --
