urn:contentItem:5S0K-7GY1-DY0W-4192-00000-00Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of Directors2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRoseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of DirectorsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, thank you so much. Happy Thursday to you, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast: Technology tumbling, shares of several big tech names fell yet again yesterday amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are now in bear market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, Amazon all in correction territory. Take a look at those numbers, the slide coming amid fears of a regulatory crackdown following Facebook's personal data scandal. Apple's CEO Tim Cook, slams Facebook.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: We're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. Privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decline weighed on the major averages once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years. We are ending the month, ending the quarter for business this week, today, actually. Dow Industrials down nine points yesterday. S&P500 down seven, and the NASDAQ down almost 60, almost one percent lower in yesterday's trade.

Let's check futures right now, we're looking at a balance at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up about 90 points, that's one- third of one percent. S&P500 up half of percent with the 12-point moving. And the NASDAQ is up almost one percent bouncing after yesterday's decline of 55 points, right now. In Europe stocks are also higher. Take a look, the major indices higher across the board with the DAX Index in Germany up one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. Best performer there as you see, up KOSPI Index and the Shanghai Composite in China. Point of a quarter percent.

White House shake up once again now. Veterans Affairs, Secretary David Shulkin is out. President Trump has nominated White House position, Admiral Ronny Jackson to take over the position. The details on Shulkin's departure, coming up right here.

Collusion in the capital newly uncovered checks show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department along with democratic leadership over the Russia investigation. The shocking revelations coming up this morning.

And Roseanne storms back despite criticism from the left. The sitcom delivers a staggering 18 million viewers in its return debut. More as the show story gets a congratulatory call from the commander-in-chief.

Plus, Blue Moon going green. The company's creator looks to brew up a new business with marijuana infused beer. We will tap in to that story, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Networks, Dagen McDowell. Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is here and CFRA Investment strategist, Lindsey Bell joining us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us, Steve.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Steve has seen it all in terms of investing, in terms of politics. So, again, nobody better to have on the program this morning.

BARTIROMO: That's true. What's the most important to you this morning? What are you looking at? Markets, obviously under pressure.

FORBES: What you want to see is what's going to be the reaction to these tech companies to the assault. They did not see it coming, not more than Microsoft 20 years ago so the intrusive coming after them. Right now, Facebook has got the biggest problem because Zuckerberg has been very poor in his response. He should've laid out. They should've had better auditing, better follow-up to make sure their rules were followed. But you know, we all knew, when we go on those things, we get those things free, but They're going to use our data to sell us (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: How did they not see that coming, Dagen? I mean --

MCDOWELL: I think Mark Zuckerberg needs to start setting his alarm for 2:00 a.m. West Coast time and watching "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". Because we've been talking about this literally for years. I have said verbatim on this program, if you don't start typing up your business in the management of it and it wasn't just the privacy data. It was like, rolling out, I've said the Facebook live video, policing terrorists on your social network. You're asking for regulators to walk in the front door. And it's not going to be (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And you also alienated conservatives by discriminating with the algorithms on Facebook and other places. Conservative websites, dumb thing to do.

BARTIROMO: That's -- and that happened throughout the election, we know that.

FORBES: Yes, it did.

BARTIROMO: You know, googling Hillary Clinton to get one set of stories. You Google Donald Trump, you get a whole different set of stories.

BELL: What I just noticed, was the Nasdaq was up to most this morning, you know, just under one percentage point. So, maybe this means the bleeding could be done for the tech sector. We saw Facebook and Google who got had the most in this privacy concern and they were flat yesterday.

BARTIROMO: That's right yesterday -- this morning we'll see how investors react. Joining the conversation, White House National Trade Council Director Peter Navarro is with us this morning. Former Reagan Budget Director, David Stockman is here. Great America PAC Chairman and former Reagan Chief White House Political Adviser, Ed Rollins joins us. And the CIO of Blackrock Global CIO with fixed income Rick Rieder is with us as well. We got a big show this morning. So, do stay with us.

We kick it off right here with technology stocks weighing on Wall Street. U.S. markets closed lower yesterday after worries set in about increased regulatory oversight. They slammed chairs at big tech companies, yesterday. Amazon among the day's worst performers losing better than four percent. After Axios reported that President Trump wants to go after Amazon on taxes or antitrust grounds. Facebook shares have fallen 14 percent this month but rose slightly yesterday at the close after the social network announced it would shut down a third-party ad targeting tool.

Meanwhile, Apple CEO Tim Cook added his voice to the scores of criticisms over Facebook's data privacy practices. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOK: The truth is we could make a ton of money if we monetized our customer, if our customer was our product, we could make a ton of money. We've elected not to do that. We care about the user experience. And we're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. I think it's -- privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting to hear Apple talk about Facebook that way, Lindsey and it really did hit a whole slack of tech companies yesterday.

BELL: It really did, and you know what, it is concerning because the tech sector really has been the bellwether for the stock market for the last year plus. So, we're going to be really watching first-quarter earnings. This is a sector though that I have to remind people, you know, the fundamentals really are intact for the tech sector. In the last six quarters you saw technology, sector companies beat earnings estimates by almost eight percentage point. That's a huge beat. Usually S&P 500 companies get four percent beat.

BARTIROMO: But does this cut into that growth? I mean, does the reason to only stops change with the bigger regulatory bite?

BELL: I mean, yes, it's definitely going to be a concern, but I do think that when you look at the market overall, you look at the 11 sectors and the S&P 500, it's going to be hard to find growth like you've seen here. And sure, Amazon and Facebook are huge components of that, but we'll see how that comes out.

BARTIROMO: That's quite a weigh, you're still looking at 16 percent growth? In earnings for the first quarter?

BELL: 18.6 percent.

BARTIROMO: Which actually exact the year for the quarter?

BELL: Sorry that's for the quarter, for the first -- for the year -- the first-quarter we're looking at 16.5 percent. That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Right, 16.5 percent for the first quarter. Steve, let me ask you about Amazon. Because once the President got in place. We were all speculating what would happen with Amazon, I mean, we know how the "Washington Post" has treated this president throughout his presidency. So, they were speculation that maybe he would want to go after Amazon. And then you look at the size of the company and the number of businesses that Amazon is in, and you do question whether or not it is getting too big. What are your thoughts on the White House? I mean, it's pushing back, by the way, on the Axios report that the President may target Amazon on tax or antitrust ground. This is what we heard yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president has said many times before he's always looking to create a level playing field for all businesses and this is no different. He's going to always look at different ways, but there aren't any specific policies on the table at this time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Steve, your thoughts.

FORBES: Mark those words, at this time. That tells you, denial, denial, denial. And what you see here is that I think, basis book the "Washington Post," because he wanted to do it. But he thought there by political protection in Washington. He didn't realize it's going to make him a target. With the Washington Post and said Donald Trump's the greatest thing since George Washington, I think you'd see a little bit of a different attitude. In terms of Amazon, free markets will work in bringing that company down just as it does with any other company over time. I'm old enough remember G.M. when that was the big bad company. IBM when that was a big tech company. Microsoft's going to take over the world. Wal- Mart was going to take over the world, now struggling. So, let the free markets play out. Well, it's amazing that Amazon has successful it's been. Jeff Bezos, by the way uses teams internally to try to keep this company fresh and on the cutting edge.

BARTIROMO: And it's hard to compete with a company that doesn't mind losing a lot of money quarter after quarter.

FORBES: Well, you see this is another lesson for Wall Street from Amazon. If you step down the terms on what you're going do your business, people cut you slack. Just like drug companies, they're always going to take 10 or 12 years to bring something to market. Amazon you know what they're doing, trying to build up volume successfully. But they make enough money to show they're not just losing money. They know how to make money if they want to do it.

MCDOWELL: Facebook largely though, I think that maybe you start to get a division in this companies that how people analyze them. Because I don't think you can value those earnings with so many question marks about Facebook's future. And I'm not talking about the regulators. I am talking about individuals who finally are waking up to abuse of their personal information and how for more than a decade Facebook hasn't given a flying flip about really protecting it and really lying to their users about what they were doing with it or, and not being upfront about privacy protections. And temple does have a line to stand on. Because these are the principles that Steve Jobs put in place from very early on it Apple. So, I think that you don't know how many users will leave, how much growth will slow at Facebook, how the time spent on the platform might shrink and how that will ultimately affect the advertising dollars that flow the Facebook. Because Facebook is raining in, (INAUDIBLE) one finger doing the limiting the information they share with data broker. So, I think, when you try to come up with a valuation on Facebook at this point, that (INAUDIBLE) is a very big question mark.

BELL: So, I think there's a huge amount of uncertainty around Facebook at this given time. And the fourth quarter we saw daily active users start to decline. And this (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And in this country, yes.

BELL: And in this country their biggest market. So, expect to see more of that in the first quarter, especially after this --

FORBES: Although you have to say Tim Cook (INAUDIBLE) could be in his position because he sells product. Facebook is just selling the experience. Not a hard product. And Facebook's motto is now under threat. And their going to have be more of an information sight.

MCDOWELL: Facebook is an advertising --

BARTIROMO: And they don't want to pay up for content either. I'm sorry Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, I was going to say, Facebook's an advertising platform. I want to pass along, follow up Mossberg on Twitter, and where actually friends on Facebook. And what Mossberg former wall street columnist. He just throughout the idea yesterday of what if Facebook offered a highly personal ad free no data mining subscription service. Where people use that to share their most personal information. That data you pay to have it protected and they don't share any of that information. Essentially the same way as a lot of people use iCloud that they share information and groups with their family members. He just threw the idea out there.

FORBES: And that had better be un-hackable.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. I don't know if anybody wants to share anything at this point.

BARTIROMO: Once you're sucked into it, that's what Facebook is betting on, you're sucked in to it. This is -- this is part of your life. They've conned you into thinking they're doing this to make the communication in your relationship better.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: No, you're not.

FORBES: Resources say the --

MCDOWELL: You know what, instead of looking at you're -- the photos your mothers posting on Facebook, how about picking up the phone and call on her.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will take a break. When we come back, another cabinet shakeup. President Trump fires V.A. secretary Davis Shulkin and taps his White House position as the replacement at the V.A. More on the Obama hold overs departure coming up.

And then ratings win for Roseanne the sitcom reboot. Getting healthy viewership in its return and the show start gets a boost from the president.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, pretty good telling this morning. We're expecting a higher opening for the broader averages, take a look, Dow is up 75 points right now. The NASDAQ is up 45 and the S&P up 10 points right now.

Meanwhile, there's this, dozens of people killed after a fire at a police station in Venezuela. Cheryl Casone has headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right Maria, at least 68 people died after a fire broke out during a riot in a police station jail in Venezuela. It reportedly started after prisoners set fire to their mattresses and authorities there say that 66 men and two women were killed. Angry families did clash with police afterwards demanding answers.

Well, Tesla shares tumbling yesterday following a credit downgrade as the company's bonds touched a new low. Tesla close down more than seven percent, that's after the stocks took a hit last week over scrutiny of self-driving car technology. Of course, that does follow that fatal accident involving a Tesla in California and overall weakness in the technology sector a part of this as well. Tesla does depend on access to capital market as it struggles to roll out its Model 3 sedan. But Tesla shares are trading higher in the free market right now, there up to two percent. So (INAUDIBLE) It's been a tough few weeks for Uber, but they've avoided one potential legal battle. The company has settled with the family of a woman, run over by one of their self-driving cars last week in Tempe, Arizona. The terms of this had not been disclosed. Uber though did suspend itself driving testing program following that accident. The fall out is spreading, other companies now are putting the brakes on their self-driving test as well in several states.

And then finally, there's this, Roseanne's return to the small screen brought in massive viewership for "ABC" in the breakout premiere and the show wasted no time taking on politics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROSEANNE BARR, ACTRESS, ROSEANNE: Aunt Jackie thinks every girl should grow up and be president. Even if they're a liar, liar, pants suit on fire. Thank you for making America great again.

JACKIE RETORTS: Have you looked at the news because now things are worse?

urn:contentItem:5W9V-B731-JBHT-D2NS-00000-00Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of Directors2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRoseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of DirectorsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, thank you so much. Happy Thursday to you, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast: Technology tumbling, shares of several big tech names fell yet again yesterday amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are now in bear market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, Amazon all in correction territory. Take a look at those numbers, the slide coming amid fears of a regulatory crackdown following Facebook's personal data scandal. Apple's CEO Tim Cook, slams Facebook.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: We're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. Privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decline weighed on the major averages once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years. We are ending the month, ending the quarter for business this week, today, actually. Dow Industrials down nine points yesterday. S&P500 down seven, and the NASDAQ down almost 60, almost one percent lower in yesterday's trade.

Let's check futures right now, we're looking at a balance at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up about 90 points, that's one- third of one percent. S&P500 up half of percent with the 12-point moving. And the NASDAQ is up almost one percent bouncing after yesterday's decline of 55 points, right now. In Europe stocks are also higher. Take a look, the major indices higher across the board with the DAX Index in Germany up one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. Best performer there as you see, up KOSPI Index and the Shanghai Composite in China. Point of a quarter percent.

White House shake up once again now. Veterans Affairs, Secretary David Shulkin is out. President Trump has nominated White House position, Admiral Ronny Jackson to take over the position. The details on Shulkin's departure, coming up right here.

Collusion in the capital newly uncovered checks show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department along with democratic leadership over the Russia investigation. The shocking revelations coming up this morning.

And Roseanne storms back despite criticism from the left. The sitcom delivers a staggering 18 million viewers in its return debut. More as the show story gets a congratulatory call from the commander-in-chief.

Plus, Blue Moon going green. The company's creator looks to brew up a new business with marijuana infused beer. We will tap in to that story, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Networks, Dagen McDowell. Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is here and CFRA Investment strategist, Lindsey Bell joining us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us, Steve.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Steve has seen it all in terms of investing, in terms of politics. So, again, nobody better to have on the program this morning.

BARTIROMO: That's true. What's the most important to you this morning? What are you looking at? Markets, obviously under pressure.

FORBES: What you want to see is what's going to be the reaction to these tech companies to the assault. They did not see it coming, not more than Microsoft 20 years ago so the intrusive coming after them. Right now, Facebook has got the biggest problem because Zuckerberg has been very poor in his response. He should've laid out. They should've had better auditing, better follow-up to make sure their rules were followed. But you know, we all knew, when we go on those things, we get those things free, but They're going to use our data to sell us (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: How did they not see that coming, Dagen? I mean --

MCDOWELL: I think Mark Zuckerberg needs to start setting his alarm for 2:00 a.m. West Coast time and watching "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". Because we've been talking about this literally for years. I have said verbatim on this program, if you don't start typing up your business in the management of it and it wasn't just the privacy data. It was like, rolling out, I've said the Facebook live video, policing terrorists on your social network. You're asking for regulators to walk in the front door. And it's not going to be (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And you also alienated conservatives by discriminating with the algorithms on Facebook and other places. Conservative websites, dumb thing to do.

BARTIROMO: That's -- and that happened throughout the election, we know that.

FORBES: Yes, it did.

BARTIROMO: You know, googling Hillary Clinton to get one set of stories. You Google Donald Trump, you get a whole different set of stories.

BELL: What I just noticed, was the Nasdaq was up to most this morning, you know, just under one percentage point. So, maybe this means the bleeding could be done for the tech sector. We saw Facebook and Google who got had the most in this privacy concern and they were flat yesterday.

BARTIROMO: That's right yesterday -- this morning we'll see how investors react. Joining the conversation, White House National Trade Council Director Peter Navarro is with us this morning. Former Reagan Budget Director, David Stockman is here. Great America PAC Chairman and former Reagan Chief White House Political Adviser, Ed Rollins joins us. And the CIO of Blackrock Global CIO with fixed income Rick Rieder is with us as well. We got a big show this morning. So, do stay with us.

We kick it off right here with technology stocks weighing on Wall Street. U.S. markets closed lower yesterday after worries set in about increased regulatory oversight. They slammed chairs at big tech companies, yesterday. Amazon among the day's worst performers losing better than four percent. After Axios reported that President Trump wants to go after Amazon on taxes or antitrust grounds. Facebook shares have fallen 14 percent this month but rose slightly yesterday at the close after the social network announced it would shut down a third-party ad targeting tool.

Meanwhile, Apple CEO Tim Cook added his voice to the scores of criticisms over Facebook's data privacy practices. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOK: The truth is we could make a ton of money if we monetized our customer, if our customer was our product, we could make a ton of money. We've elected not to do that. We care about the user experience. And we're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. I think it's -- privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting to hear Apple talk about Facebook that way, Lindsey and it really did hit a whole slack of tech companies yesterday.

BELL: It really did, and you know what, it is concerning because the tech sector really has been the bellwether for the stock market for the last year plus. So, we're going to be really watching first-quarter earnings. This is a sector though that I have to remind people, you know, the fundamentals really are intact for the tech sector. In the last six quarters you saw technology, sector companies beat earnings estimates by almost eight percentage point. That's a huge beat. Usually S&P 500 companies get four percent beat.

BARTIROMO: But does this cut into that growth? I mean, does the reason to only stops change with the bigger regulatory bite?

BELL: I mean, yes, it's definitely going to be a concern, but I do think that when you look at the market overall, you look at the 11 sectors and the S&P 500, it's going to be hard to find growth like you've seen here. And sure, Amazon and Facebook are huge components of that, but we'll see how that comes out.

BARTIROMO: That's quite a weigh, you're still looking at 16 percent growth? In earnings for the first quarter?

BELL: 18.6 percent.

BARTIROMO: Which actually exact the year for the quarter?

BELL: Sorry that's for the quarter, for the first -- for the year -- the first-quarter we're looking at 16.5 percent. That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Right, 16.5 percent for the first quarter. Steve, let me ask you about Amazon. Because once the President got in place. We were all speculating what would happen with Amazon, I mean, we know how the "Washington Post" has treated this president throughout his presidency. So, they were speculation that maybe he would want to go after Amazon. And then you look at the size of the company and the number of businesses that Amazon is in, and you do question whether or not it is getting too big. What are your thoughts on the White House? I mean, it's pushing back, by the way, on the Axios report that the President may target Amazon on tax or antitrust ground. This is what we heard yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president has said many times before he's always looking to create a level playing field for all businesses and this is no different. He's going to always look at different ways, but there aren't any specific policies on the table at this time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Steve, your thoughts.

FORBES: Mark those words, at this time. That tells you, denial, denial, denial. And what you see here is that I think, basis book the "Washington Post," because he wanted to do it. But he thought there by political protection in Washington. He didn't realize it's going to make him a target. With the Washington Post and said Donald Trump's the greatest thing since George Washington, I think you'd see a little bit of a different attitude. In terms of Amazon, free markets will work in bringing that company down just as it does with any other company over time. I'm old enough remember G.M. when that was the big bad company. IBM when that was a big tech company. Microsoft's going to take over the world. Wal- Mart was going to take over the world, now struggling. So, let the free markets play out. Well, it's amazing that Amazon has successful it's been. Jeff Bezos, by the way uses teams internally to try to keep this company fresh and on the cutting edge.

BARTIROMO: And it's hard to compete with a company that doesn't mind losing a lot of money quarter after quarter.

FORBES: Well, you see this is another lesson for Wall Street from Amazon. If you step down the terms on what you're going do your business, people cut you slack. Just like drug companies, they're always going to take 10 or 12 years to bring something to market. Amazon you know what they're doing, trying to build up volume successfully. But they make enough money to show they're not just losing money. They know how to make money if they want to do it.

MCDOWELL: Facebook largely though, I think that maybe you start to get a division in this companies that how people analyze them. Because I don't think you can value those earnings with so many question marks about Facebook's future. And I'm not talking about the regulators. I am talking about individuals who finally are waking up to abuse of their personal information and how for more than a decade Facebook hasn't given a flying flip about really protecting it and really lying to their users about what they were doing with it or, and not being upfront about privacy protections. And temple does have a line to stand on. Because these are the principles that Steve Jobs put in place from very early on it Apple. So, I think that you don't know how many users will leave, how much growth will slow at Facebook, how the time spent on the platform might shrink and how that will ultimately affect the advertising dollars that flow the Facebook. Because Facebook is raining in, (INAUDIBLE) one finger doing the limiting the information they share with data broker. So, I think, when you try to come up with a valuation on Facebook at this point, that (INAUDIBLE) is a very big question mark.

BELL: So, I think there's a huge amount of uncertainty around Facebook at this given time. And the fourth quarter we saw daily active users start to decline. And this (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And in this country, yes.

BELL: And in this country their biggest market. So, expect to see more of that in the first quarter, especially after this --

FORBES: Although you have to say Tim Cook (INAUDIBLE) could be in his position because he sells product. Facebook is just selling the experience. Not a hard product. And Facebook's motto is now under threat. And their going to have be more of an information sight.

MCDOWELL: Facebook is an advertising --

BARTIROMO: And they don't want to pay up for content either. I'm sorry Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, I was going to say, Facebook's an advertising platform. I want to pass along, follow up Mossberg on Twitter, and where actually friends on Facebook. And what Mossberg former wall street columnist. He just throughout the idea yesterday of what if Facebook offered a highly personal ad free no data mining subscription service. Where people use that to share their most personal information. That data you pay to have it protected and they don't share any of that information. Essentially the same way as a lot of people use iCloud that they share information and groups with their family members. He just threw the idea out there.

FORBES: And that had better be un-hackable.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. I don't know if anybody wants to share anything at this point.

BARTIROMO: Once you're sucked into it, that's what Facebook is betting on, you're sucked in to it. This is -- this is part of your life. They've conned you into thinking they're doing this to make the communication in your relationship better.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: No, you're not.

FORBES: Resources say the --

MCDOWELL: You know what, instead of looking at you're -- the photos your mothers posting on Facebook, how about picking up the phone and call on her.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will take a break. When we come back, another cabinet shakeup. President Trump fires V.A. secretary Davis Shulkin and taps his White House position as the replacement at the V.A. More on the Obama hold overs departure coming up.

And then ratings win for Roseanne the sitcom reboot. Getting healthy viewership in its return and the show start gets a boost from the president.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, pretty good telling this morning. We're expecting a higher opening for the broader averages, take a look, Dow is up 75 points right now. The NASDAQ is up 45 and the S&P up 10 points right now.

Meanwhile, there's this, dozens of people killed after a fire at a police station in Venezuela. Cheryl Casone has headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right Maria, at least 68 people died after a fire broke out during a riot in a police station jail in Venezuela. It reportedly started after prisoners set fire to their mattresses and authorities there say that 66 men and two women were killed. Angry families did clash with police afterwards demanding answers.

Well, Tesla shares tumbling yesterday following a credit downgrade as the company's bonds touched a new low. Tesla close down more than seven percent, that's after the stocks took a hit last week over scrutiny of self-driving car technology. Of course, that does follow that fatal accident involving a Tesla in California and overall weakness in the technology sector a part of this as well. Tesla does depend on access to capital market as it struggles to roll out its Model 3 sedan. But Tesla shares are trading higher in the free market right now, there up to two percent. So (INAUDIBLE) It's been a tough few weeks for Uber, but they've avoided one potential legal battle. The company has settled with the family of a woman, run over by one of their self-driving cars last week in Tempe, Arizona. The terms of this had not been disclosed. Uber though did suspend itself driving testing program following that accident. The fall out is spreading, other companies now are putting the brakes on their self-driving test as well in several states.

And then finally, there's this, Roseanne's return to the small screen brought in massive viewership for "ABC" in the breakout premiere and the show wasted no time taking on politics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROSEANNE BARR, ACTRESS, ROSEANNE: Aunt Jackie thinks every girl should grow up and be president. Even if they're a liar, liar, pants suit on fire. Thank you for making America great again.

JACKIE RETORTS: Have you looked at the news because now things are worse?

ROSEANNE: Not on the real news.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The show wrapped up an astonishing 18.2 million viewers over two back to back episodes. Making it the second most-watched entertainment program of the season. Behind (INAUDIBLE) after the Super Bowl, we should add. President Trump even gave Roseanne Barr a call to extend his congratulations on the shows early success. We should take a look at Disney, ABC's parent company down nine percent year to date. But if the show keeps doing well, the stock may change course as well, Maria. Roseanne Barr of course, has been very vocal about the fact she is a supporter of President Trump and you're going to see that in the show she says.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, look, it got a great reaction yesterday. We were talking during the break. It feels like this is the conversation happening across America right now. And to see family fighting over, it's real.

MCDOWELL: I was saying that, the reason the ratings on the Oscars just were awful. Jimmy Kimmel again, the jokes about the President, the Vice President about Trump, they -- mind that -- mind that so much. It's not funny anymore. But this is true to Roseanne's character. And again, its finding the comedy in the division in families, and the division in America. Whether they're just making fun of say, the president's looks. Which, those jokes have been told.

BARTIROMO: And it's not funny.

MCDOWELL: And a lot of people didn't find it funny in the first place. And another thing, they brought in Whitney Cummings who is a star comedian and writer. She was a real important addition to the show. And these actors are phenomenal. John Goodman, Laurie Metcalf, people were longing for these characters to come back and see these actors at work.

BARTIROMO: You watch it? Did you watch it Steve?

FORBES: I'm going to have to watch on YouTube. But yes, I'm glad that it's happening, and I think it also shows Hollywood, get out of your bubble. You'll find an audience out there. They make that mistake in movies and making on T.V. It's amazing. They're supposed to be in the business of free enterprise in terms of meeting the needs and wants of their audiences. Hello.

BARTIROMO: Get out of your bubble. You're right.

BELL: I think it's a good way to bring the millennials back to T.V. as well. Nostalgic for those folks.

BARTIROMO: They also may bring people together. We'll keep watching that. Coming up, new Russia pro-bombshell, wait till you hear this. Newly uncovered text messages that I told you were coming out. They're between the FBI officials, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page strongly suggesting a coordination between Obama's White House, former Senate Democrats and the CIA early in the Russia investigation. The outrage coming up.

And then, this bugs for you, taking on a new meaning. Beer company Blue Moon launching a marijuana infused brew, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another White House shakeup. President Trump ousting Veterans Affairs Secretary, David Shulkin. The President took the twitter last night to make the replacement. Here's what he writes. I am pleased to announce that I intend to nominate highly respected Admiral Ronnie L. Jackson, MD. As the new Secretary of the V.A. Jackson had been serving as the White House physician remember prior to disappointment. Joining us now to talk more about that, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle. Lea, good to see you. Thanks for joining us.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) the holdover from the Obama administration? We know that, but initially the President was pretty high on Shulkin. Your reaction to this decision.

GABRIELLE: Well, I think this has a lot to do with the fact that people lost trust in him because of this I.G. report that came out basically saying that he the fraud -- he used government money to take his wife on a trip that his chief of staff doctored an e-mail to make it, you know, to make it look like it was legitimate. Went to Europe then they accepted tickets to Wimbledon. And he said that these tickets were from a close personal friend because then that would be acceptable by government regulations.

By, he couldn't even remember this personal -- close personal friends first name when interviewed. So, I think what this really comes down to is sort of the loss of trust and it's really unfortunate because there are a lot of veteran organizations who felt like he was doing a really good job. And there's -- there've been a lot of improvements in the V.A. you know, modernizing the appeals process, improves peace and satisfaction, decrease wait times, increase access to mental health care. But when you are, you know, in this sort of position and you are prudently using government money for personal trips, that sort of the end of it for you.

BELL: Does this have anything to do with the fact that, you know, the administration wanted to move forward with government subsidizing private care and they kind of sort of turned on him?

GABRIELLE: You know, I think that that's probably what people in his court would say. But I mean, look, when you're in this position and you're being trusted by veterans who expect a certain level of integrity among themselves and among the people who are supposed to be supporting them. I think, that's what it really comes down to more than anything. People can say that politics was involved, people can say a lot of different things. But I think, bottom line is you can't be in this kind of position and supposedly leaving the V.A. where integrity is paramount, and you know, the getting free tickets to Wimbledon. He did pay -- he did payback for the trip. He tried to --

FORBES: Ronnie Jackson has a very good reputation. Is there any possibility of getting vouchers for veterans so, instead of trying to do these internal reforms, some hospitals do it, some don't do it so well. Huge deregulations still in place. You can just take your coupon or whatever, stamp with whatever and go to whatever hospital you want to go whatever treatment you want and get that kind of competition and shake the thing up instead of trying to do a top-down.

GABRIELLE: Yes, I mean, I think that is certainly one of the ideas that people have thought of for correcting some of the issues on the V.A. Of course, there's you know, the cost benefit analysis and trying to figure out what the overall cost would be. I don't know how Admiral Jackson going to run the V.A. I think, one of the questions people are raising about him is, you know, he's been serving the military since 1995. He's done a combat deployment where he did combat medicine. He's a very good reputation. And he started working, caring for the president health of the George W. Bush administration. But the question is his executive experience. You know, and I think that, that's really important in the V.A. because he is -- he is a career physician and military officer. The question is, you know, what kind of executive experience is he going to be able to bring to the table?

FORBES: And will he get to appoint personnel who can round out his team?

BARTIROMO: That's an important point. And he did a good job on that press conference about the president health about a month ago.

GABRIELLE: He did, he put him on a diet.

BARTIROMO: I want to get to the border -- I want to get to the border wall. The President is posting photos of the U.S.-Mexican border wall construction to Twitter. He posted it yesterday. He showed a united front for the President. 380 sheriffs from 40 states signed a letter calling for increased border security. They say this: Without border security and immigration reform, more Americans will continue to be victims of crime. Now is the time to act. Lea, what's your take here?

GABRIELLE: You know, I think this backs up what voters felt when they voted President Trump into office. I think that, illegal immigration was a huge issue in this election and I think that not just law enforcement, but the people of the united states want some sort of a border wall. They want to plug the jug on the illegal immigration.

BARTIROMO: But I was struck by the -- by the conversation around the defense spending. Dagen, I wonder, what do you think about this? Numerous reports now say that the President has suggested funding the construction of the newly 2000-mile long Mexican border wall through the U.S. military budget. We know, well, what went on to get that military money in place, that's spending disaster $1.3 trillion, but they needed to fund the military. Will some of that money go to the border wall?

MCDOWELL: They should fight the Republicans and President Trump frankly needed to fight harder for the funding of border security. Wouldn't they get $1.6 billion in border security?

FORBES: Just maintenance.

MCDOWELL: Proper fencing. Again, not cracking down on sanctuary cities where the Congress has the power to purse, they didn't put any restrictions or limits on how the cities use federal funding. I think that that -- I think, to now try to take the money from the military is questionable and another thing, you know what, President Trump where in this all -- this all comes together. He ran on draining the swamp and instead he has his cabinet secretary spending taxpayer money essentially to buy fan boats, so they can navigate the swamp that's even murkier than it was before.
