urn:contentItem:5W2T-9RC1-DY0W-435T-00000-00Roseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of Directors2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRoseanne Storms Back; Facebook Shuts Down Third-Party Ad Targeting Tool and Privacy Update; Fire at Police Station Kills At Least 68 In Venezuela; Tesla Credit Down Grade; Uber Settles Accident Case; DOJ and FBI under Investigation for Possible FISA Abuse; Koreas To Hold Summit; Susan Rice Named To Netflix's Board Of DirectorsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, thank you so much. Happy Thursday to you, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast: Technology tumbling, shares of several big tech names fell yet again yesterday amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are now in bear market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, Amazon all in correction territory. Take a look at those numbers, the slide coming amid fears of a regulatory crackdown following Facebook's personal data scandal. Apple's CEO Tim Cook, slams Facebook.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: We're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. Privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decline weighed on the major averages once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years. We are ending the month, ending the quarter for business this week, today, actually. Dow Industrials down nine points yesterday. S&P500 down seven, and the NASDAQ down almost 60, almost one percent lower in yesterday's trade.

Let's check futures right now, we're looking at a balance at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up about 90 points, that's one- third of one percent. S&P500 up half of percent with the 12-point moving. And the NASDAQ is up almost one percent bouncing after yesterday's decline of 55 points, right now. In Europe stocks are also higher. Take a look, the major indices higher across the board with the DAX Index in Germany up one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. Best performer there as you see, up KOSPI Index and the Shanghai Composite in China. Point of a quarter percent.

White House shake up once again now. Veterans Affairs, Secretary David Shulkin is out. President Trump has nominated White House position, Admiral Ronny Jackson to take over the position. The details on Shulkin's departure, coming up right here.

Collusion in the capital newly uncovered checks show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department along with democratic leadership over the Russia investigation. The shocking revelations coming up this morning.

And Roseanne storms back despite criticism from the left. The sitcom delivers a staggering 18 million viewers in its return debut. More as the show story gets a congratulatory call from the commander-in-chief.

Plus, Blue Moon going green. The company's creator looks to brew up a new business with marijuana infused beer. We will tap in to that story, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Networks, Dagen McDowell. Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is here and CFRA Investment strategist, Lindsey Bell joining us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us, Steve.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Steve has seen it all in terms of investing, in terms of politics. So, again, nobody better to have on the program this morning.

BARTIROMO: That's true. What's the most important to you this morning? What are you looking at? Markets, obviously under pressure.

FORBES: What you want to see is what's going to be the reaction to these tech companies to the assault. They did not see it coming, not more than Microsoft 20 years ago so the intrusive coming after them. Right now, Facebook has got the biggest problem because Zuckerberg has been very poor in his response. He should've laid out. They should've had better auditing, better follow-up to make sure their rules were followed. But you know, we all knew, when we go on those things, we get those things free, but They're going to use our data to sell us (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: How did they not see that coming, Dagen? I mean --

MCDOWELL: I think Mark Zuckerberg needs to start setting his alarm for 2:00 a.m. West Coast time and watching "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". Because we've been talking about this literally for years. I have said verbatim on this program, if you don't start typing up your business in the management of it and it wasn't just the privacy data. It was like, rolling out, I've said the Facebook live video, policing terrorists on your social network. You're asking for regulators to walk in the front door. And it's not going to be (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And you also alienated conservatives by discriminating with the algorithms on Facebook and other places. Conservative websites, dumb thing to do.

BARTIROMO: That's -- and that happened throughout the election, we know that.

FORBES: Yes, it did.

BARTIROMO: You know, googling Hillary Clinton to get one set of stories. You Google Donald Trump, you get a whole different set of stories.

BELL: What I just noticed, was the Nasdaq was up to most this morning, you know, just under one percentage point. So, maybe this means the bleeding could be done for the tech sector. We saw Facebook and Google who got had the most in this privacy concern and they were flat yesterday.

BARTIROMO: That's right yesterday -- this morning we'll see how investors react. Joining the conversation, White House National Trade Council Director Peter Navarro is with us this morning. Former Reagan Budget Director, David Stockman is here. Great America PAC Chairman and former Reagan Chief White House Political Adviser, Ed Rollins joins us. And the CIO of Blackrock Global CIO with fixed income Rick Rieder is with us as well. We got a big show this morning. So, do stay with us.

We kick it off right here with technology stocks weighing on Wall Street. U.S. markets closed lower yesterday after worries set in about increased regulatory oversight. They slammed chairs at big tech companies, yesterday. Amazon among the day's worst performers losing better than four percent. After Axios reported that President Trump wants to go after Amazon on taxes or antitrust grounds. Facebook shares have fallen 14 percent this month but rose slightly yesterday at the close after the social network announced it would shut down a third-party ad targeting tool.

Meanwhile, Apple CEO Tim Cook added his voice to the scores of criticisms over Facebook's data privacy practices. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOK: The truth is we could make a ton of money if we monetized our customer, if our customer was our product, we could make a ton of money. We've elected not to do that. We care about the user experience. And we're not going to traffic in your personal -- your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. I think it's -- privacy to us is a human right. It's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting to hear Apple talk about Facebook that way, Lindsey and it really did hit a whole slack of tech companies yesterday.

BELL: It really did, and you know what, it is concerning because the tech sector really has been the bellwether for the stock market for the last year plus. So, we're going to be really watching first-quarter earnings. This is a sector though that I have to remind people, you know, the fundamentals really are intact for the tech sector. In the last six quarters you saw technology, sector companies beat earnings estimates by almost eight percentage point. That's a huge beat. Usually S&P 500 companies get four percent beat.

BARTIROMO: But does this cut into that growth? I mean, does the reason to only stops change with the bigger regulatory bite?

BELL: I mean, yes, it's definitely going to be a concern, but I do think that when you look at the market overall, you look at the 11 sectors and the S&P 500, it's going to be hard to find growth like you've seen here. And sure, Amazon and Facebook are huge components of that, but we'll see how that comes out.

BARTIROMO: That's quite a weigh, you're still looking at 16 percent growth? In earnings for the first quarter?

BELL: 18.6 percent.

BARTIROMO: Which actually exact the year for the quarter?

BELL: Sorry that's for the quarter, for the first -- for the year -- the first-quarter we're looking at 16.5 percent. That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Right, 16.5 percent for the first quarter. Steve, let me ask you about Amazon. Because once the President got in place. We were all speculating what would happen with Amazon, I mean, we know how the "Washington Post" has treated this president throughout his presidency. So, they were speculation that maybe he would want to go after Amazon. And then you look at the size of the company and the number of businesses that Amazon is in, and you do question whether or not it is getting too big. What are your thoughts on the White House? I mean, it's pushing back, by the way, on the Axios report that the President may target Amazon on tax or antitrust ground. This is what we heard yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president has said many times before he's always looking to create a level playing field for all businesses and this is no different. He's going to always look at different ways, but there aren't any specific policies on the table at this time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Steve, your thoughts.

FORBES: Mark those words, at this time. That tells you, denial, denial, denial. And what you see here is that I think, basis book the "Washington Post," because he wanted to do it. But he thought there by political protection in Washington. He didn't realize it's going to make him a target. With the Washington Post and said Donald Trump's the greatest thing since George Washington, I think you'd see a little bit of a different attitude. In terms of Amazon, free markets will work in bringing that company down just as it does with any other company over time. I'm old enough remember G.M. when that was the big bad company. IBM when that was a big tech company. Microsoft's going to take over the world. Wal- Mart was going to take over the world, now struggling. So, let the free markets play out. Well, it's amazing that Amazon has successful it's been. Jeff Bezos, by the way uses teams internally to try to keep this company fresh and on the cutting edge.

BARTIROMO: And it's hard to compete with a company that doesn't mind losing a lot of money quarter after quarter.

FORBES: Well, you see this is another lesson for Wall Street from Amazon. If you step down the terms on what you're going do your business, people cut you slack. Just like drug companies, they're always going to take 10 or 12 years to bring something to market. Amazon you know what they're doing, trying to build up volume successfully. But they make enough money to show they're not just losing money. They know how to make money if they want to do it.

MCDOWELL: Facebook largely though, I think that maybe you start to get a division in this companies that how people analyze them. Because I don't think you can value those earnings with so many question marks about Facebook's future. And I'm not talking about the regulators. I am talking about individuals who finally are waking up to abuse of their personal information and how for more than a decade Facebook hasn't given a flying flip about really protecting it and really lying to their users about what they were doing with it or, and not being upfront about privacy protections. And temple does have a line to stand on. Because these are the principles that Steve Jobs put in place from very early on it Apple. So, I think that you don't know how many users will leave, how much growth will slow at Facebook, how the time spent on the platform might shrink and how that will ultimately affect the advertising dollars that flow the Facebook. Because Facebook is raining in, (INAUDIBLE) one finger doing the limiting the information they share with data broker. So, I think, when you try to come up with a valuation on Facebook at this point, that (INAUDIBLE) is a very big question mark.

BELL: So, I think there's a huge amount of uncertainty around Facebook at this given time. And the fourth quarter we saw daily active users start to decline. And this (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: And in this country, yes.

BELL: And in this country their biggest market. So, expect to see more of that in the first quarter, especially after this --

FORBES: Although you have to say Tim Cook (INAUDIBLE) could be in his position because he sells product. Facebook is just selling the experience. Not a hard product. And Facebook's motto is now under threat. And their going to have be more of an information sight.

MCDOWELL: Facebook is an advertising --

BARTIROMO: And they don't want to pay up for content either. I'm sorry Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, I was going to say, Facebook's an advertising platform. I want to pass along, follow up Mossberg on Twitter, and where actually friends on Facebook. And what Mossberg former wall street columnist. He just throughout the idea yesterday of what if Facebook offered a highly personal ad free no data mining subscription service. Where people use that to share their most personal information. That data you pay to have it protected and they don't share any of that information. Essentially the same way as a lot of people use iCloud that they share information and groups with their family members. He just threw the idea out there.

FORBES: And that had better be un-hackable.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. I don't know if anybody wants to share anything at this point.

BARTIROMO: Once you're sucked into it, that's what Facebook is betting on, you're sucked in to it. This is -- this is part of your life. They've conned you into thinking they're doing this to make the communication in your relationship better.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: No, you're not.

FORBES: Resources say the --

MCDOWELL: You know what, instead of looking at you're -- the photos your mothers posting on Facebook, how about picking up the phone and call on her.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will take a break. When we come back, another cabinet shakeup. President Trump fires V.A. secretary Davis Shulkin and taps his White House position as the replacement at the V.A. More on the Obama hold overs departure coming up.

And then ratings win for Roseanne the sitcom reboot. Getting healthy viewership in its return and the show start gets a boost from the president.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, pretty good telling this morning. We're expecting a higher opening for the broader averages, take a look, Dow is up 75 points right now. The NASDAQ is up 45 and the S&P up 10 points right now.

Meanwhile, there's this, dozens of people killed after a fire at a police station in Venezuela. Cheryl Casone has headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right Maria, at least 68 people died after a fire broke out during a riot in a police station jail in Venezuela. It reportedly started after prisoners set fire to their mattresses and authorities there say that 66 men and two women were killed. Angry families did clash with police afterwards demanding answers.

Well, Tesla shares tumbling yesterday following a credit downgrade as the company's bonds touched a new low. Tesla close down more than seven percent, that's after the stocks took a hit last week over scrutiny of self-driving car technology. Of course, that does follow that fatal accident involving a Tesla in California and overall weakness in the technology sector a part of this as well. Tesla does depend on access to capital market as it struggles to roll out its Model 3 sedan. But Tesla shares are trading higher in the free market right now, there up to two percent. So (INAUDIBLE) It's been a tough few weeks for Uber, but they've avoided one potential legal battle. The company has settled with the family of a woman, run over by one of their self-driving cars last week in Tempe, Arizona. The terms of this had not been disclosed. Uber though did suspend itself driving testing program following that accident. The fall out is spreading, other companies now are putting the brakes on their self-driving test as well in several states.

And then finally, there's this, Roseanne's return to the small screen brought in massive viewership for "ABC" in the breakout premiere and the show wasted no time taking on politics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROSEANNE BARR, ACTRESS, ROSEANNE: Aunt Jackie thinks every girl should grow up and be president. Even if they're a liar, liar, pants suit on fire. Thank you for making America great again.

JACKIE RETORTS: Have you looked at the news because now things are worse?

ROSEANNE: Not on the real news.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The show wrapped up an astonishing 18.2 million viewers over two back to back episodes. Making it the second most-watched entertainment program of the season. Behind (INAUDIBLE) after the Super Bowl, we should add. President Trump even gave Roseanne Barr a call to extend his congratulations on the shows early success. We should take a look at Disney, ABC's parent company down nine percent year to date. But if the show keeps doing well, the stock may change course as well, Maria. Roseanne Barr of course, has been very vocal about the fact she is a supporter of President Trump and you're going to see that in the show she says.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, look, it got a great reaction yesterday. We were talking during the break. It feels like this is the conversation happening across America right now. And to see family fighting over, it's real.

MCDOWELL: I was saying that, the reason the ratings on the Oscars just were awful. Jimmy Kimmel again, the jokes about the President, the Vice President about Trump, they -- mind that -- mind that so much. It's not funny anymore. But this is true to Roseanne's character. And again, its finding the comedy in the division in families, and the division in America. Whether they're just making fun of say, the president's looks. Which, those jokes have been told.

BARTIROMO: And it's not funny.

MCDOWELL: And a lot of people didn't find it funny in the first place. And another thing, they brought in Whitney Cummings who is a star comedian and writer. She was a real important addition to the show. And these actors are phenomenal. John Goodman, Laurie Metcalf, people were longing for these characters to come back and see these actors at work.

BARTIROMO: You watch it? Did you watch it Steve?

FORBES: I'm going to have to watch on YouTube. But yes, I'm glad that it's happening, and I think it also shows Hollywood, get out of your bubble. You'll find an audience out there. They make that mistake in movies and making on T.V. It's amazing. They're supposed to be in the business of free enterprise in terms of meeting the needs and wants of their audiences. Hello.

BARTIROMO: Get out of your bubble. You're right.

BELL: I think it's a good way to bring the millennials back to T.V. as well. Nostalgic for those folks.

BARTIROMO: They also may bring people together. We'll keep watching that. Coming up, new Russia pro-bombshell, wait till you hear this. Newly uncovered text messages that I told you were coming out. They're between the FBI officials, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page strongly suggesting a coordination between Obama's White House, former Senate Democrats and the CIA early in the Russia investigation. The outrage coming up.

And then, this bugs for you, taking on a new meaning. Beer company Blue Moon launching a marijuana infused brew, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another White House shakeup. President Trump ousting Veterans Affairs Secretary, David Shulkin. The President took the twitter last night to make the replacement. Here's what he writes. I am pleased to announce that I intend to nominate highly respected Admiral Ronnie L. Jackson, MD. As the new Secretary of the V.A. Jackson had been serving as the White House physician remember prior to disappointment. Joining us now to talk more about that, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle. Lea, good to see you. Thanks for joining us.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) the holdover from the Obama administration? We know that, but initially the President was pretty high on Shulkin. Your reaction to this decision.

GABRIELLE: Well, I think this has a lot to do with the fact that people lost trust in him because of this I.G. report that came out basically saying that he the fraud -- he used government money to take his wife on a trip that his chief of staff doctored an e-mail to make it, you know, to make it look like it was legitimate. Went to Europe then they accepted tickets to Wimbledon. And he said that these tickets were from a close personal friend because then that would be acceptable by government regulations.

By, he couldn't even remember this personal -- close personal friends first name when interviewed. So, I think what this really comes down to is sort of the loss of trust and it's really unfortunate because there are a lot of veteran organizations who felt like he was doing a really good job. And there's -- there've been a lot of improvements in the V.A. you know, modernizing the appeals process, improves peace and satisfaction, decrease wait times, increase access to mental health care. But when you are, you know, in this sort of position and you are prudently using government money for personal trips, that sort of the end of it for you.

BELL: Does this have anything to do with the fact that, you know, the administration wanted to move forward with government subsidizing private care and they kind of sort of turned on him?

GABRIELLE: You know, I think that that's probably what people in his court would say. But I mean, look, when you're in this position and you're being trusted by veterans who expect a certain level of integrity among themselves and among the people who are supposed to be supporting them. I think, that's what it really comes down to more than anything. People can say that politics was involved, people can say a lot of different things. But I think, bottom line is you can't be in this kind of position and supposedly leaving the V.A. where integrity is paramount, and you know, the getting free tickets to Wimbledon. He did pay -- he did payback for the trip. He tried to --

FORBES: Ronnie Jackson has a very good reputation. Is there any possibility of getting vouchers for veterans so, instead of trying to do these internal reforms, some hospitals do it, some don't do it so well. Huge deregulations still in place. You can just take your coupon or whatever, stamp with whatever and go to whatever hospital you want to go whatever treatment you want and get that kind of competition and shake the thing up instead of trying to do a top-down.

GABRIELLE: Yes, I mean, I think that is certainly one of the ideas that people have thought of for correcting some of the issues on the V.A. Of course, there's you know, the cost benefit analysis and trying to figure out what the overall cost would be. I don't know how Admiral Jackson going to run the V.A. I think, one of the questions people are raising about him is, you know, he's been serving the military since 1995. He's done a combat deployment where he did combat medicine. He's a very good reputation. And he started working, caring for the president health of the George W. Bush administration. But the question is his executive experience. You know, and I think that, that's really important in the V.A. because he is -- he is a career physician and military officer. The question is, you know, what kind of executive experience is he going to be able to bring to the table?

FORBES: And will he get to appoint personnel who can round out his team?

BARTIROMO: That's an important point. And he did a good job on that press conference about the president health about a month ago.

GABRIELLE: He did, he put him on a diet.

BARTIROMO: I want to get to the border -- I want to get to the border wall. The President is posting photos of the U.S.-Mexican border wall construction to Twitter. He posted it yesterday. He showed a united front for the President. 380 sheriffs from 40 states signed a letter calling for increased border security. They say this: Without border security and immigration reform, more Americans will continue to be victims of crime. Now is the time to act. Lea, what's your take here?

GABRIELLE: You know, I think this backs up what voters felt when they voted President Trump into office. I think that, illegal immigration was a huge issue in this election and I think that not just law enforcement, but the people of the united states want some sort of a border wall. They want to plug the jug on the illegal immigration.

BARTIROMO: But I was struck by the -- by the conversation around the defense spending. Dagen, I wonder, what do you think about this? Numerous reports now say that the President has suggested funding the construction of the newly 2000-mile long Mexican border wall through the U.S. military budget. We know, well, what went on to get that military money in place, that's spending disaster $1.3 trillion, but they needed to fund the military. Will some of that money go to the border wall?

MCDOWELL: They should fight the Republicans and President Trump frankly needed to fight harder for the funding of border security. Wouldn't they get $1.6 billion in border security?

FORBES: Just maintenance.

MCDOWELL: Proper fencing. Again, not cracking down on sanctuary cities where the Congress has the power to purse, they didn't put any restrictions or limits on how the cities use federal funding. I think that that -- I think, to now try to take the money from the military is questionable and another thing, you know what, President Trump where in this all -- this all comes together. He ran on draining the swamp and instead he has his cabinet secretary spending taxpayer money essentially to buy fan boats, so they can navigate the swamp that's even murkier than it was before. I'm talking about like even Ben Carson and the $31,000 dining table and chairs. Again, they need to start answering for this and heads are going to keep rolling.

GABRIELLE: I want to agree with this, President Trump is going to have an issue if he tries to use military funding.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's what I figure.

GABRIELLE: We go back to the constitution Article one section nine clause seven says, No money shall be drawn from the treasury except in consequence of appropriation made by law. And then there is of course U.S. code that says that appropriation shall be applied only to the objects for which appropriations were made except as otherwise provided by law. He's going have to go back to Congress in order to -- in order to get money from the military that was appropriate specifically when it comes down to balance the power the way our government --

MCDOWELL: And the Democrats he's fighting back about this wall.

FORBES: Terms of illegal immigration and crime. Why do the Democrats think that's a winning issue being on the other side of trying to crackdown?

BARTIROMO: It's pretty extraordinary.

GABRIELLE: I mean, I think, this is a whole bigger issue we're about to get in to, we don't have time. But I think, you know, for the Democrats is that our population of our has changed and they have more voters that come from that population that are becoming Democrats now. So, I think that there's a political reason that Democrats do.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll watch all that Lea. Thank you. Thank you very much. Lea Gabrielle, joining us there.

Coming up, the date is set. Kim Jong-un and South Korea's leader have set a date for their historic nuclear summit talks. Details on that, plus how this affects trade, coming up next.

And then we continue to watch the volatility in markets, particularly technology after the Facebook fallout and the impact on the broader market this morning. Tech stocks are higher across the board. Take a look, Facebook now up one and a quarter percent. We're back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning, everybody, welcome back, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us, happy Thursday, it is Thursday, March 29th, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Markets are higher this morning. Take a look at futures, indicating a gain at the start of trading by about 75 points on the Dow, 10 points higher on the S&P and 41 points higher on the NASDAQ.

Today marks the final trading day of the month and the first quarter. It's been a wild quarter, that's for sure. The Dow and the S&P 500 are on track for their first quarterly decline in more than two years. It's been a tough quarter on stocks, down about four percent, as you can see. Stocks closing the day, yesterday for the downside, the NASDAQ was the worst performer, down almost one percent, as technology traded lower.

Global markets this morning, check European indices right now, they are higher across the board, FT-100 up a third of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris up two-thirds of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany, up almost one percent. In Asia overnight, stocks ended higher, and it was just edging higher, really, the best performer was China, Shanghai Composite, up one and a quarter percent.

And historic summit on the Korean peninsula, North Korea's dictator Kim Jong-un, excited to meet with South Korea's president, Moon Jae-in, next month, the implications from this meeting, coming up. Plus, North Korea eyed in a Bitcoin heists, Pyongyang's hackers reportedly stealing from an exchange as the Kim regime hunts for funds. And the CME group makes a major acquisition, the exchange giant acquiring any NEX group for more than $5 billion. There's a chart of the CME group, this morning.

And a fall from grace for Blue Apron, the company now has a market evaluation of roughly $350 million, that's down from nearly $2 billion in its IPO last year. Plus, Netflix, making a change to its board of directors, the streaming giant says it will add President Obama's National Security Adviser, Susan Rice, to the board, the choices raising some eyebrows, this morning. And a rocking mountain high for Blue Moon, for the beer giant, adding a new ingredient to its beer, marijuana, we'll tell you about it.

But first, our top story this half an hour, FBI theory over nearly uncovered text messages, which also these were coming. GOP Congressional investigators tell Fox News the texts between Peter Strzok and Lisa Page strongly suggest coordination between officials in the Obama administration, Former Senate Democratic Leadership, the CIA, the FBI and the Justice Department, during the early stages of the Russia investigation. No shock here.

In one of the text messages, Strzok texts Page this, internal joint cyber cd intel piece for D, which refers to former FBI Director James Comey, is a scene setter for Former Chief of Staff under Obama, Denis McDonough's brief, Trainor, the head of the FBI cyber division, directed all cyber info be pulled. I'd let Bill and Jim hammer it out first, though it would be best for D, the director, to have it before the Wednesday White House session.

Here's what House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes, who's been leading the charge on this, reacted to the new developments.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: The Democrats appear like they weaponize to some degree, the intelligence services, you know, by using the foreign intelligence surveillance apparatus in this country, to go and target the opposition campaign, is totally unacceptable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I want to bring in Republican Strategist and Former Nevada State GOP Chairman, Amy Tarkanian, Amy, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

AMY TARKANIAN,FORMER CHAIRWOMAN, NEVADA STATE GOP: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: The more texts that come out really put the story together in terms of how they came up with this whole Russia probe. What do you make of all of this?

TARKANIAN: Well, you know, it's really -- it's frightening, you have Sen. Reid who was briefed by then CIA Director Brennan. And those documents supposedly being leaked and used for a Yahoo news story to actually catapult this into these allegations, it is mind blowing that something like this could actually take place. You know, you have the FBI that's supposed to be, you know, basically, and an independent agency and what we find in this, they are abusing their power.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, it certainly appears, Steve, that they were all in this, in terms of a fix, coming together with a story about a probe, about a story about Russia collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, which never existed, and they seemed to be all in on it.

FORBES: Absolutely. That's the real collusion. And what's amazing is they tried to redact some of this stuff, tried to hide it, obviously. They'd never thought this guy was going to win. They were going to do everything they could to keep him from winning, and then when he won, you know what they said, oh, you know what, and they continue to cover up and continued doing these illegal things. They should be in jail for abusing their authority.

BARTIROMO: It's a massive abuse of power. That's why the story enrages me. I just -- they have these powerful seats and they used that power to actually take down a political enemy, Donald Trump.

FORBES: And what they don't want to say is --

BARTIROMO: Based on nothing.

FORBES: What they don't want to say is, the President then President Obama, probably knew all about it.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's what these text messages are leading. Amy, what do you think about that? I mean, how far up the chain did this go? Did Obama direct all of this?

TARKANIAN: Well, you know, that's a very good question, and I would actually find it very hard to believe that he didn't know about this, taking place.

BARTIROMO: of course.

TARKANIAN: You know, we are finding out more and more about the abuse that the FBI and CIA have been doing over -- actually, for quite some time, not just, you know, recently. So, you know, it stinks to high heaven and I think it does start at the top.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, we know that the FBI and the Department of Justice are now officially under investigation for the alleged FISA abuses in the Russia probe, following allegations last month by GOP House Intel Committee members. DOJ Inspector General Michael Horowitz announced yesterday, he's reviewing what FBI officials and the Department of Justice knew, when they asked a Federal Court to let them spy on Former Trump Campaign Adviser, Carter Page, during the presidential campaign.

Here's what House Intel Committee Chairman Devin Nunes and House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte has to say about the investigation, last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: This is not a simple move for the Inspector General to make, to go after the top people in the FBI.

REP. BOB GOODLATTE (R-VA), CHAIR, HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: You can't have the most important law enforcement organization in the world, conducting itself in the manner it did in 2016 and on into 2017.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Just extraordinary. And you know, Bob Goodlatte joined me last two weeks ago on Sunday Morning Futures. He said he was going to subpoena for the documents, then they slow walked all the documents. So they start this investigation and they say, look, we want 1.2 million documents, they sent 3,000, over six months. It's just outrageous.

MCDOWELL: Oh, but now, Christopher Ray, he's adding more men.

BARTIROMO: He's doubling it up.

MCDOWELL: Yes. He's adding more manpower and womanpower to it.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

FORBES: He has got to make a decision, whether he's going to be the guy who cleans up the FBI and saves the FBI or go down. He cannot (INAUDIBLE) he's due announcing, oh, we're trying our best. He's got to make a fundamental decision.

BARTIROMO: Amy, what I want to know is, will there be any justice here? Look, we know that the people who had these powerful seats have abused their power, I'm talking about Jim Comey, Andrew McCabe, Bruce or, the Department of Justice and a couple of others, not to mention Peter Strzok and his girlfriend, Lisa Page. Are we going to see justice here?

TARKANIAN: You know, with somebody like President Trump, being in office, I sure would hope there is going to be, but it seems to be a pattern that's happened over and over where these individuals are actually just released and let free, and it's very disappointing, and I think the public is really tired of it. I would hope so.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TARKANIAN: I would like to see that take place, finally.

BARTIROMO: You know what else is incredible? When you look at the participation of the CIA and John Brennan and Mr. Clapper, who have been all over CNN, all year, so critical of this president, how arrogant is this? They were also in on it, it appears.

FORBES: Yes, and even more arrogant, Comey, coming out with a book.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I know.

FORBES: Hello.

BARTIROMO: I know.

FORBES: Come on.

BARTIROMO: All of this went on, on your watch. And you're over this, selling your book, and again, attacking this president. I mean, it's a joke.

FORBES: Yes, they should throw the book at him.

MCDOWELL: Jim Comey is going to go on all these talk shows. There, he is not going to get pressed, people are not familiar, they choose not to familiarize themselves with what was going on at the FBI under his leadership, they're not going to press him on it. They're going to ask him how much he hates Trump on a scale from 1 to 10.

BARTIROMO: Right. And what they tried to do is muddy the waters. They come up with lots of different information to just confuse everything, when we actually know, very clearly, what went on here.

FORBES: Well, can the Attorney General Sessions step up to the plate and make sure that this is going to be done with the department he has today?

BARTIROMO: That's what he needs to do. Will he do it?

FORBES: That's the question.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we'll see.

FORBES: Especially with that number 2 he has as part of that collusion.

BARTIROMO: Rod Rosenstein, yes, exactly.

MCDOWELL: And while Rosenstein signed off on the renewal of the FISA warrant, the last one, the last renewal. So he's got -- his hands aren't clean on that either.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point. Well, they did renew that FISA warrant, four times, right, once, and an additional three times, Amy Tarkanian, with the same information, the same dossier they used to just keep renewing it so that they can keep spying on him. Final word from you, Amy, we've got to jump.

TARKANIAN: Yes. Well, I actually -- I hope that Attorney General Sessions does stop up. I know that there have been a number of Republicans in the base that have been disappointed with him, moving so slowly. So, let's hope that he goes in the right direction with this.

BARTIROMO: Well, we certainly will keep on it. Amy, good to see you, thanks so much, Amy Tarkanian joining us there. Coming up, singing the blues, meal kit company, Blue Apron, shares plummet, are investors losing their appetite for last year's hot IPO? The stock is down five and a half percent.

And then this, Former National Security Adviser and Ambassador Susan Rice, is tasked to get on the board of Netflix. This comes after her former boss, Barack Obama, is reportedly working with the media company as well, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The date is set for a historic meeting between North and South Korea. Cheryl Casone with the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Well, Maria, South Korea announcing today that President Moon Jae- in will meet with North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, on April 27th. A rare summit between the two countries, which have only met twice before. Japan, also, is putting out fillers to North Korea about a bilateral summit. Discussions are reportedly underway there. All these developments follow Kim's surprise visit to China earlier this week. It was his first trip outside of his country since he assumed power back in 2011.

And separately, investigators in South Korea are looking into North Korea's possible involvement in a Bitcoin heist. The Wall Street Journal is reporting this morning that investigators are looking to see if North Korea was behind the hacking of Youbit, it's a South Korean cryptocurrency exchange. Officials believe that North Korea is so desperate for currency because of the crushing sanctions that they've turn to Bitcoin for relief.

OK. Breaking overnight, CME Group buying Britain's NEX Group for $5.4 billion. NEX owns the biggest electronic platform for trading U.S. treasuries. CME says the deal is also going to expand its presence in Europe and Asia. CME Group owns the Chicago Border Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange. CME shares up merely nine percent so far this year.

All right. Former National Security Advisor and U.S. Ambassador, Susan Rice, now has a new role on Netflix's board of directors. Rice saying, Netflix is "a cutting-edge company whose leadership, high-quality productions, and unique culture I deeply admire." Rice's former boss, President Obama, may not be far behind her. Earlier this month, the New York Times reports that the former president and first lady were in talks with Netflix for a deal, possibly involving exclusive content for Netflix subscribers. He's already appeared with David Letterman on Netflix, we should say. Shares of Netflix up 95 percent, 95, over the last year.

Finally, there is this. Blue Moon Beer is adding a little green. The brewery company is launching three marijuana infused beers. They're alcohol free, but again, they're filled marijuana. They're going to be served chilled only available in Colorado. They're going to starts that this fall. Company says, they will begin with light beer, a wheat beer, and a stout beer just to start. Shares of Blue Moon's parent company, Molson Coors, down about eight percent so far, this year. Pot-infused beer, Maria. Those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and, you know, marijuana is legal in Colorado. Here's a good tweet on that Susan Rice story. Dagen, what do you think about Susan Rice joining the board of Netflix? Here's a tweet from Karen Nelson, she says: "Big mistake, Netflix," and then a picture of Susan Rice, "I spy." Big mistake, I spy. I don't know, she unmasked. She did all that unmasking, right?

MCDOWELL: And then, she lied about the Benghazi attacks that she went on national television and lied to the American people and lied to the families about why those individuals were killed. Oh, I remember it was a video.

BARTIROMO: It was a video. And it happens to be September 11th, but it was a video.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

BARTIROMO: Not a terrorist attack. But, I don't know, but her experience to go on the board of Netflix.

MCDOWELL: It's a love fest, baby. Come on! A lot of documentaries that they have on there and I watch a lot of them, they're very, very left- leaning.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. OK.

BELL: This isn't going to help them in the current regulatory environment, I don't think. Regulatory is currently in Washington.

BARTIROMO: While this focuses on a bigger bite from Washington, you see.

FORBES: Consider the reception of Roseanne and what the hasting is doing with Netflix bringing on these far left-wing people is going to hurt. And what does he expect to get? He loves crony capitalism. He loves regulation and helps Netflix. It's so called net neutrality debate which is regulating the Internet to help the big guys. What's his game plan on this? What does think he's going to get out of it?

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's a very good point.

FORBES: It alienates half the country. You can have your opinions and voice them. But, you've got a company that you're supposed to be steward of, come on.

BARTIROMO: Especially since we just saw the success of Roseann, really important to put that out. We're going to take a break. When we come back, pulling on the apron strings. Blue Apron seems to be in trouble after its flashy IPO last year. We're taking a look at what the future holds for the meal kit company next. And then, of course, there's Tesla, stay with us on that.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Investors are hoping meal kit company, Blue Apron, can cook something up as the stocks lived again. Lauren Simonetti with all the details now, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN REPORTER: It's an ugly tart, Maria. I mean, this is the stock that in June of last year, IPO-ed a $10.00 a share. It's at a $1.88. We were talking at one point of like $2 billion value slashed to $360 million. So, it's certainly running on fumes. Mismanagement by the company, over spending. Competition not only with the -- look at the char -- not only the likes of Amazon but also with other meal preparation kit companies like Hello Fresh, which is bigger, believe it or not, than Blue Apron. So, you know, if they're running on fumes, and someone to come in to buy them and who should that person be? Rumors say Costco could be a potential buyer. But is this the state of the IPO market this year? Not necessarily the case. In fact, Renaissance IPO is out with some new numbers for the first quarter which ends today. We've seen 43 IPOs raising $15.6 billion. This is being led mostly by tech and by technology companies.

Speaking of tech, Dropbox, Unicorn, they IPO-ed on Friday. I remember Friday because that was the day when the big tech companies like Facebook and Amazon tumbled three percent each. And you have Dropbox IPO-ing on that day, shares popping 36 percent. And look at this, they IPO-ed at 21, not even a week ago, and they're trading in the premarket at $31.00 a share. So, so far so good. Tuesday, we hear from Spotify. So, we'll see how IPO market holds up. Do you guys know Yeti, by the way? The Yeti Coolers.

MCDOWELL: It's a cooler. They look cool. It's a cooler.

SIMONETTI: Well, I'm glad you say it like that because they dropped their plans; they withdrew their listing. And speculation is, it could have something to do with the steel and aluminum tariffs, because obviously that's what's in their tumblers, and their thermoses, and coolers or they don't want to go the way of, you know, GoPro -- you have a great premium product.

MCDOWELL: As my father told me, I know those Yeti Coolers look real cool hanging off the back of somebody's pickup truck. But he said, they're a bear to get into. And he said, I can't get my bud quick enough. That's how he --

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: We had long family discussions at the dinner table about the flaws in Yeti Coolers.

SIMONETTI: A premium product, not that many. They don't -- I guess they don't want to go the way of GoPro, for instance, but nonetheless, is bags questions: what is the state on IPO market right after a good first quarter?

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting to see such a strong quarter in the first quarter ever while markets were volatile. Markets were actually down for the first quarter. But the IPOs did well. Lauren, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Could be the worst margin in 17 years.

BARTIROMO: Lauren Simonetti, we'll follow it. Still ahead, as questions mount about your privacy on Facebook, we've got the sever Genie to change ASAP to protect yourself. That's next hour right here in MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast: trouble for technology. Shares of several big tech companies under pressure --

FORMER Ireland and Leinster star Mike Ross has swapped the rugby pitch for the boardroom after being appointed commercial director for Wizuda. The Dublin business expects to see an increase in demand for its software ahead of the introduction of the general date protection regulation.

It means firms must ensure personal data is protected and will use safe methods to transfer data.

Ross has a "keen interest in and knowledge of technology".

Wizuda added: "He begins his role at a crucial time for the senior management team as they experience a significant increase in demand for their innovative software."

Oct 26, 2019( Dakota Free Press: http://dakotafreepress.comDelivered by Newstex)   https://i1.wp.com/dakotafreepress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/ROUNDS-ON-ZUCKERBUCK.jpgMaybe that's what Mike's after.The idea of Mark Zuckerberg or any other private citizen being in charge of the money supply should terrify any sensible policymaker or person who uses money. But incredibly, Senator Marion Michael Rounds thinks digital currency[1] stamped 'In Facebook We Trust' is a good idea[2]: Rounds published a letter claiming that 'there is promise in cryptocurrencies and digital payments' and that 'it is here to stay'. In spite of mounting regulatory pressure and scrutiny[3] surrounding Libra, he wrote[4]: 'I write regarding concerns recently expressed by a number of my colleagues about involvement in the Libra Association. It is profoundly disappointing that my colleagues chose to address your peers in such an ominous tone, which I fear may put a chill on innovation in the long run.' urn:contentItem:5X8F-N4F1-JD3S-J38W-00000-00Roundtable: Digging into the data2019-10-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRoundtable: Digging into the data

Having high quality data is a prerequisite if policy and decisions are to be truly evidence-based, Jonathan Owen reports on a CS Live round table where leading civil servants came together to share ideas on how government can improve the way data is used in helping design and deliver services

Cabinet Office permanent secretary John Manzoni chaired the discussion, sponsored by global digital transformation specialists Cognizant, which was held at Civil Service Live in London.

Britain is "one of the most digital governments in the world" and data has "enormous potential for us" Manzoni said.

"The question is making better decisions, how can government use data more effectively to improve how we design and deliver services?"

Tom Smith, managing director of the data science campus at the Office for National Statistics, paid tribute to some "really excellent work going on" in government. The campus has 70 people recruited from industry, academia and across government, and its role is "across the government's statistical service as an analysis function."

Smith commented that the "government and the civil service has a huge skill set." The question is how those are shared and "how do we build up cross-government capability for data sharing and also for sharing the tools and techniques that we are developing?"

However, the government is not necessarily the best placed to exploit its own data, according to Cathrine Armour, director of the customer division at the UK Hydrographic Office.

"How can government use its own data more effectively? Perhaps we shouldn't be using it, perhaps, particularly where it's not GDPR collected, we need to provide it to others who have better domain expertise and understand our customers and their journeys more than we do," she said.

"Not all data is created equal, we need to be really conscious of the fact that we want integrity of the decisions that we are making, we need integrity of the data we are proving to make those decisions," Armour added.

On the issue of building up skills within government, Steven Steer, head of data, Ofgem commented: "We need to have expertise ourselves to be able to have good approaches to policies on the market. He cited the rise of online consultations in recent years as an example of how digital technology can increase participation in government. In Ofgem's case, the organisation is moving towards "self service of regulation" and "crowd sourcing of regulatory rules," he said.

"We need data and digital capabilities to enable the right decision to be made, not necessarily to be the ones directly doing it," Steer commented.

The issue of greater standardisation over the collection, sharing and usage of data dominated the discussion. Marcus Bell, director at the Cabinet Office's race disparity unit, expressed concern over a lack of standardisation in data.

He outlined how different departments use different words and terms to define ethnicity, something which is part of a wider issue. "Big tech is based on linking together different data sets. If the currency is all different it's almost impossible to do that, so I'm wondering if there's a case for a bit more top down prescription about data standards," he said.

'We now have a whole wealth of data, all collected in lots of different ways, the question then is can we share it?'

The case for common standards was reiterated byErika Lewis, deputy director, national data strategy at the Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport. "We are pulling together, with ONS and GDS, some work for a spending review package but the focus will be on some cross governmental work but also a big push on standards because that's exactly what I've been hearing since I arrived in DCMS, that's the big thing, we've got to grab it by the horns," she said.

Using master data management, where there is a central source of data that everything else spins off from, "is a very standard way of doing things in the private sector" and could be useful for government too, according to Matthew O'Kane, VP EMEA head of AI and analytics, Cognizant.

In terms of the wealth of data available, not just within government, Julie Pierce, director of openness, data and digital, Food Standards Agency, commented: "There's a huge amount of global data out there that's open and published and that's a huge asset to us all."

Potential legal issues around the use of data were raised by Wendy Hardaker, commercial law director at the Government Legal Department. She warned: "It's about the way in which you've collected the data, often, as to what you can then do with it, and you can fall into all sorts of elephant traps if you've not thought about that at the start of the process. We now have a whole wealth of data, all collected in lots of different ways, the question then is can we share it?"

Some of the difficulties around the use of data revolve around trust, according to Yatin Mahandru, head of public sector, Cognizant. "The citizen's trust in the data and what government are going to do with it and the service the government is going to provide, and then also the trust between departments when you are exchanging that data as to what it's going to be used for, whether it's enforcement or something else."

Manzoni brought the discussion to a close by outlining what he called "three big dilemmas as we nudge forward." The first is the "top down bottom up one, do we let a thousand flowers bloom, do we put in the standards, at what point do we do this?"

The second surrounds open data. "Is it a total muddle or does it have value for somebody else and if it has value for somebody else why would I give my data away when I could sell it?" he asked.

Third is the skills issue. "How do we actually teach people to frame the question right, so have we got that right or are we focussing on the high-end data scientists or actually, should we do something completely different?"
