urn:contentItem:5R25-TWP1-DXH2-612F-00000-00Roy Moore Accuser Speaks Out; Press Pounds Trump Over Moore; More Franken Accusers Emerge; Hill Hit by Harassment Claims; Trump Hits CNN International; Media Awash in Harassment; Trump Tangles with Time; Suit Clouds CNN's Future; Rand Paul's Wife Rips Media; The Downfall Of Charlie Rose And Suspension Of New York Time's Glenn Thrush Over Sexual Harassment Allegations; Twitter Feud Between Donald Trump And Lavar Ball And The NFL; People Mad Over Silicon Valley Tech Giants2017-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisMEDIA BUZZ11:00 AM ESTEllison Barber, Gayle Trotter, Juan Williams, Frank Luntz, Liz Claman, Gayle Trotter, Juan Williams, Frank Luntz, Steve HiltonNEWSDomestic112601cb.269Roy Moore Accuser Speaks Out; Press Pounds Trump Over Moore; More Franken Accusers Emerge; Hill Hit by Harassment Claims; Trump Hits CNN International; Media Awash in Harassment; Trump Tangles with Time; Suit Clouds CNN's Future; Rand Paul's Wife Rips Media; The Downfall Of Charlie Rose And Suspension Of New York Time's Glenn Thrush Over Sexual Harassment Allegations; Twitter Feud Between Donald Trump And Lavar Ball And The NFL; People Mad Over Silicon Valley Tech GiantsHoward Kurtz

HOWARD KURTZ, MEDIA BUZZ SHOW HOST, FOX NEWS: On "Buzz Media" this Sunday, television icon Charlie Rose fired by three networks after a devastating report in The Washington Post.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: CBS News and PBS take Charlie Rose off the air after at least eight women accused him of sexual harassment.

GAYLE KING, CO-ANCHOR, CBS THIS MORNING: They called and said are you OK? I am not okay. After reading that article in The Post, it was deeply disturbing, troubling, and painful for me to read.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Rose apologizes for inappropriate behavior, but how did his misconduct stay secret for so long? This as The New York Times suspends star White House correspondent Glenn Thrush over harassment allegations. And as Roy Moore accuser Leigh Corfman goes on NBC, President Trump defends the embattled Alabama senate candidate and is denounced by many of the pundits.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LEIGH CORFMAN, ROY MOORE ACCUSER: He basically laid out some blankets on the floor of his living room and proceeded to seduce me. I guess you would say. And during the course of that, he removed my clothing.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Let me just tell you, Roy Moore denies it. And by the way, he totally denies it.

CHRIS HAYES, HOST, ALL IN WITH CHRIS HAYES: The president of the United States effectively endorsed an accused child molester for U.S. Senate. I'm just going to repeat that to let it sink in.

JESSE WATTERS, JOURNALIST, FOX NEWS: The lesson if you listen to what the president said is, if you deny the allegations, you get the benefit of the doubt in politics. That is a strange --

JOHN HEILEMANN, JOURNALIST, NBC NEWSAND MSNBC: Donald trump didn't seem to find problem to be on the side of neo-Nazis and apparently he doesn't see a problem being on the side of the accused child predators either.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: President Trump obviously taking a pragmatic approach to the Alabama senate race. A Republican victory would at least ensure the senate GOP would preserve its majority by the its current margin.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KURTZ: What is behind this tsunami of criticism for the president? This as three more women accused Al Franken of probing them. He keeps on apologizing. And Congressman John Conyers admits settling a former staffer suit that included claims of sexual harassment. Is the press covering these cases fairly?

Plus, Trump getting into Twitter words with NFL protester Marshawn Lynch and the father of UCLA basketball player the president got sprung from Chinese custody. The pundits scorecard says he's picking the wrong fights, but is that true? I'm Howard Kurtz and this is "Media Buzz."

After President Trump's initial statement that Roy Moore should get out of the Alabama senate race if the sexual misconduct allegations against him are true, he suddenly seems to shift his stance. That was after Leigh Corfman, who first told The Washington Post that Moore sexually accosted her when she was 14 appeared on "The Today Show" and explain why she did not speak out when Moore first got into politics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CORFMAN: My children were small. I was a single parent. And when you're in that situation, you do everything you can to protect your own. So when The Washington Post sought me out, I didn't come looking for this. This fell in my lap.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: When the president took questions from reporters, he made clear he wanted the former judge in the senate over Democrat Doug Jones.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We don't need a liberal person in there, a Democrat, Jones.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Is an accused child molester better than a Democrat? It is an accused child molester better than a Democrat?

TRUMP: Well, he denies it. He denies it. I mean, if you look at what is really going on and you look at all the things that have happened over the last 48 hours, he totally denies it. He says it did not happen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: And the New York tabloids reacting with these headlines. Striking the same theme. Joining us now to analyze the coverage: Ellison Barber, Fox News correspondent here in Washington; Gayle Trotter, political commentator who contributes to The Daily Caller and The Hill; and Juan Williams, co- host of The Five.

Ellison, President Trump's comments as we just saw causing a huge media uproar, because he was seen as essentially endorsing Roy Moore in the Alabama race. Has the White House pushed back on that?

ELLISON BARBER, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: It's a non-endorsement endorsement. Initially you had the White House saying, as we heard earlier, saying that if these allegations are true, he should step down. And they repeatedly said that President Trump wants the voters of Alabama to decide. He had noticeably not said anything about it until those comments on the south lawn.

Then yo had the comments on the south lawn. Then you had him tweet again today that it's better than a Pelosi or Schumer puppet. So, I mean, there is only so much they can push back at some point. The White House can say as much as they want that he wants the voters of Alabama to decide, whatever, that if he thinks the allegations are true, then he should step down.

I believe they have also said that he considered the allegations troubling. It doesn't really matter when President Trump comes out and then says what he has said. I think we have to take his words more than anything from the press secretary.

KURTZ: Gale, much of the media are portraying this is a dramatic shift for President Trump. And they say, well, if he is essentially siding with Roy Moore or attacking a Democrat which is kind of the same thing, that shows he doesn't care about these sexual harassment allegations. Is that a lift (ph) the president making?

GAYLE TROTTER, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: That is a lift (ph). And just think about what you said, his previous position was that if the allegations were true, he should step down. And then when he spoke to the press this week, he said that he totally denied it. Forty years was a long time ago. There have been multiple races where this hasn't come up.

So I would say he has changed his position. And when asked by the media specifically was he going to go down to Alabama and campaign for Roy Moore, he said I will decide next week. So, saying that he has taken a different position is an unfair characterization and saying that he is endorsing Roy Moore is inconsistent as well with the facts.

KURTZ: The press does not seem to be buying that argument. They are saying that in effect and this is not everybody in journalism, but many say that in effect, if he is saying the Democrat is terrible and you got to listen to Roy Moore's denials, he is kind of sending a signal. So is there a leak (INAUDIBLE) question I asked Gayle?

JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST, THE FIVE: No, I think you have to put it in the political context, Howie, and the political context is this. Remember, President Trump did not back Judge Moore in the republican primary in the state of Alabama.

KURTZ: Right.

WILLIAMS: He picked the incumbent, the appointee Luther Strange. So, what you get is a situation where then once Roy Moore won the seat, there was pressure on him, I think he felt somewhat, you know, hey maybe I made the wrong call earlier. My base is with Judge Moore. The (INAUDIBLE) community is strong there.

KURTZ: Is the press reading him right? Is the press --

WILLIAMS: I think they're right.

KURTZ: -- interpreting what he is doing here with --

WILLIAMS: I do not think there is any question that Steve Bannon who has been involved in this and is part of the push in the press by the way at Breitbart, to get people to look at Roy Moore differently has also influenced President Trump.

So, while it may be fear (ph), as Gayle points out, I have to say, well, he really hasn't changed. I think the statement that he made going out to the helicopter before the Thanksgiving holiday was far more aggressive and public in terms of support for Moore than anything that he had done before.

BARBER: I think part of the context too is President Trump did not speak about it until the south lawn. So in terms of did he change is a matter of he said this, his press team said this.

KURTZ: Many of these politicians try to avoid the media allegations. So for example, Roy Moore, the initial radio conversation with Sean Hannity, has not talked to a journalist. Now he may be can do that, of course he got twice as many accusers now as in the beginning, but the president is constantly in photo ops and opportunities, he ultimately does not have that option, does he? Just saying nothing?

BARBER: Not necessarily. Sometimes, you see instances where reporters shout questions and he keeps walking by, so he can certainly strategically avoid them if he wants or not answer. I do think whether people love or hate President Trump, I think the most thing that everyone agrees on is that he usually does not, I don't think, usually ignore a whole lot of questions.

I think when the questions are thrown at him sometimes, I think his press office would wish that he doesn't. I think he usually answers or responds with Twitter or whatever. He usually is better about responding. That is why it was particularly notable initially and why so many people talked about ho he hadn't commented on Roy Moore.

KURTZ: He engages with reporters a lot more than he used to. More than most presidents, I must say. Now, you've seen stories, segments trying to resurrect the harassment allegations against Donald Trump himself. About a dozen women who made these allegations at the end of the campaign last year. He has called them horrible liars. Is it fair or unfair for the media now to revive that issue?

TROTTER: Certainly relevant for the media to bring that up, because it is historically interesting and it gives color to the story, and it certainly gives an insight into what President Trump is thinking. And if he truly believes that these women were liars, then that could show why he would be more likely to support Roy Moore and think that there should be a presumption of innocence.

And like Juan was saying, I was a little surprised that he did not come out and say, well, I was right, I supported the challenger to Roy Moore. And like Ellison was saying, there is no filter on him and so he has the ability to go out there and say that. It is a little surprising that he didn't say, hey, I was right, you should have listened to me.

WILLIAMS: I think what surprised me too to pick up on this point is, that he then opened the door to the media criticism of his past and going back. Now the argument would be that voters are different than a private employer. You mentioned some cases at the top of the show, Charlie Rose, Glenn Thrush and others. These are people who are in the public eye, but they really work for a private enterprise, a media organization.

KURTZ: There is no verdict by the voters.

WILLIAMS: Correct. But here with President Trump, there was a verdict by the voters. And some people say, well, does that mean that they were judge and jury with regard to the sexual harassment claims? Or did they prefer him as president? I don't know if they were truly judge and jury, but I think lots of people in President Trump's camp say, that issue is dead because the voters --

KURTZ: Yes, I don't say that, some people misinterpreted what I said on the show last week, just noting that there was an election at these allegations. Ivanka Trump certainly has said she believes the women involved. The president is taking a different stance. And I guess, you know, that does lead lots of questions of why these women accused you.

You say that they are not telling the truth and maybe he is skeptical of Roy Moore. Let me go a little more here because the spotlight now is shifting to the Democrats. If I can just go through, three more accusers since last week saying that Senator Al Franken grabbed them. But in photo ap, one picture of one woman, at least we can put that up, Linsay Menz. He has apologized again. He said he crossed line. And senator is going to talk to Minnesota reporters later today.

Eighty-eight-year-old John Conyers, Democrat, dean of the House actually, first reported by BuzzFeed that he secretly used $27,000 taxpayers money to settle a former staffer suite that included allegations of sexual harassment. He denies it. In terms of media coverage, is this all becoming a blur? Is it muddying the waters about who did what?

BARBER: I do not know if I would say a blur. I guess it depends on how you think of blurt? I think in terms of just the amount of information that is being thrown at a reader, maybe there is a lot to process and digest. I feel like everyday, I am trying to keep up with it.

KURTZ: Right, and we do this for a living.

BARBER: Right.

KURTZ: But also, are there important distinctions to be made about the level of conduct or harassment compared to people who have been accused of sexual assault or rape?

BARBER: Yes, absolutely. I think the difference can be seen usually in the reporting. I think that is the reporters job, is to accurately portray sort of where this falls and whether it is child molester, rape accusation or something else, but that doesn't mean it should be covered simply because there are other major --

WILLIAMS: Right. Let me just say. Another distinction to be made, in the Conyers case, the allegation -- I think it is more of an allegation now. You could correct me if I'm wrong. He used taxpayer dollars --

KURTZ: No, that's a fact.

WILLIAMS: that is office funds to buy off or silence --

KURTZ: Yes.

WILLIAMS: -- this woman.

KURTZ: This was just a couple of years ago and it was done in secret.

WILLIAMS: Right. That is the case, that is different than what we are talking about. Other cases, I do not know about settlements, but the idea that you're using public funds, if that is not an exception, not common practice on Capitol Hill, I think that is a problem. And that is why the Detroit Free Press in their editorial call for him to resign.

KURTZ: Yes, because there's a clear public interest here because of taxpayer money. But now you have this other case involving Republican Congressman Joe Barton of Texas. InfoWars posted a naked picture of the congressman that he had sent to a girlfriend, consensual relationship.

The Washington Post has a recording of Barton telling the woman he would report to Capitol police if she tries to expose him. But some people are saying Joe Barton is kind of a victim here of revenge porn.

TROTTER: It is hard to see that he is a victim of anything besides his own stupidity. And when you look at a public figure like this in a position of power, in a position of public notoriety, and you look at the privacy laws that govern this kind of rape or porn revenge statute, then it is hard to say how that will play out with someone like this.

KURTZ: Yes. I just want to point that he is not accused of harassing anyone, but certainly may be guilty of the conduct, as yo said. Let me get a break here. (Repeats with no changes to text) By July 6 (Reuters) - Browsing online during lockdown, Jessica Friend spotted a pair of Ray-Ban sunglasses she liked, but the price tag made the 30-year-old Ohio resident think twice. What persuaded her to click ‘buy’, Fri...

(Repeats with no changes to text) By July 6 (Reuters) - Browsing online during lockdown, Jessica Friend spotted a pair of Ray-Ban sunglasses she liked, but the price tag made the 30-year-old Ohio resident think twice. What persuaded her to click ‘buy’, Friend said, was the short-term credit offered by Afterpay, which split the $260 payment into four interest-free instalments. Afterpay is among a handful of alternative credit firms which offer small loans, mostly to online shoppers, and make their money by charging merchants a 4%-6% commission. These buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) firms have benefited from a shift to online shopping during the coronavirus crisis in countries including the United States, where state aid has also boosted retail sales. “I’m more inclined to use them because they make it easier to afford to get the things I want all at once ... and when I want to splurge on something,” Friend said of the loans. Some investors are now betting shoppers will stay away from stores as coronavirus cases rise again in several countries around the world, boosting business for BNPL firms. But swelling subscriber numbers may also increase bad loans, mainly among first-time users who are more likely to default. And as job losses rise and government aid ebbs, the business model will face its first real test in a recession. “Much still hinges on any virus second waves and government wherewithal to keep boosting demand,” said Andrew Mitchell of Ophir Asset Management which owns shares in Melbourne-based Afterpay, whose market value has risen to $12.55 billion from over $100 million four years ago. While a move to online shopping was underway before the pandemic, the shift has accelerated under lockdown and Afterpay signed up more than a million new active U.S. customers between March and early May, taking its overall base there to 9 million. Meanwhile retailers desperate to move merchandise have also become more receptive to partnerships with BNPL firms, which unlike credit cards or mortgages, make loans instantly. Klarna, Europe’s biggest fintech start-up, said that since March enquiries from retailers who may want to partner with it jumped by 20% on average globally. With 7.9 million U.S. subscribers, Sweden’s Klarna has since signed up outdoor gearmaker The North Face, Disney’s streaming service and cosmetics retailer Sephora. Most of the growth has been in higher-margin discretionary spend categories such as fashion and fitness gear, said Puneet Dikshit, a McKinsey partner in New York, who expects the sector to generate $7 billion to $8 billion in volumes this year in the United States, growing by more than 150% annually. (For an interactive version, click here tmsnrt.rs/2BHL5qC ) Although fears of credit losses sparked a sector-wide sell-off in March, the entry of big tech investors and rising subscriber numbers have since supported a sharp recovery, with stocks now at record highs. ‘TURN OFF THE TAPS’ The pandemic forced most companies to tighten their risk settings, which they say may push up loan rejection rates, although Afterpay, Klarna, Zip and Sezzle declined to provide specific numbers. “BNPL operators can turn off the taps and quickly throttle down growth if repayment risks increase,” Mitchell said. While Afterpay, with bad loans totalling 1% of its loan book as of March, changed its requirements so that customers had to pay a quarter of their loan upfront, co-founder Nick Molnar said rejection rates were roughly in line with the start of the year. Molnar said an overwhelming majority of Afterpay customers, whose average transaction value is A$150, pay back on time, while loans on new purchases are denied to those who do not. Although some brokerages expect Afterpay to turn a profit by 2022, rising costs to finance expansion and credit losses that eat into receivables are likely to mean BNPLs, which operate on thin margins, remain unprofitable for some time. Klarna saw credit losses more than double in the first three months of the year to about 0.7% of underlying sales as it expanded in Europe and the United States, where regulation of the sector is almost non-existent. Only California has said BNPL firms need a license, and fined some for lending without one. In Australia, where the industry first took off on the back of easy funding, the corporate regulator is set to release a follow-up report this year to one it issued in 2018 raising concerns about users becoming overextended and calling for BNPLs to be regulated in line with other credit services. Companies, investors and analysts agree that young people with stimulus money in their wallets are driving sales and BNPL shoppers that Reuters spoke to were all under 35 and bought household items, as well as skin care products and clothes. “The vast majority of our customers have income levels of under $75,000, so I would say the majority probably have a stimulus check,” said Charlie Youakim, CEO of Sezzle, one of the smaller firms. The younger demographic is harder to assess because they lack credit history, meaning most companies use algorithms to run real-time eligibility checks and assess risk of default. “Our internal engine assesses risk taking various parameters into consideration which also will include consumer payment history, what is being purchased and is combined with varying third-party data sources and authentication solutions,” Klarna spokeswoman Aoife Houlihan said. Sydney-based Zip, with bad debts of just over 2% of receivables, said it assesses shoppers’ public information and credit scores. Around one in 100 customers is late with payments each month, spokesman Matthew Abbott said, adding that Zip recently tightened eligibility rules, leading to higher rejection rates.

(Repeats Friday’s story without changes) LONDON, Aug 21 (Reuters) - 1/ POWELL TAKES (VIRTUAL) CENTRE STAGE A lot has been riding on the Fed in recent months: risk assets have surged on the back of its do-whatever-it-takes approach to propping up the economy with asset purchases and zero-bound rates during the pandemic crisis. Now a key challenge is how to spur inflation. Fed Chair Jerome Powell may give hints on Thursday on the opening day of the Jackson Hole conference, where he will discuss the central bank’s monetary policy framework review. The review looks at how to revamp Fed tools to guide the economy. As part of that, investors have been anticipating details on possible changes to how it targets inflation. To guard against the possibility of higher prices ahead, investors have loaded up on assets like gold and TIPs. Still, while five-year five-year forwards - an inflation gauge - have been rising, the measure remains below the Fed’s 2% target. -Fed Chair Powell to speak on Fed’s framework review next Thursday -Coronavirus legacy will be weak global inflation: economists 2/NATIONAL SERVICE Chinese banks are expected to show the scars of the pandemic and the domestic economic slowdown for the first time when they report half-yearly earnings, having bucked the Western banking sector’s downward trend in the first quarter. The big five state banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), China Construction Bank (CCB), and Bank of China (BoC), kick off earnings season on Aug. 28. The government has pressed banks into service: financial institutions have been told to sacrifice 1.5 trillion yuan ($217 billion) in profit this year to support companies by lowering lending rates and fees, and deferring loan payments. Beijing wants new loans and overall financing to top last year’s while the banking regulator has asked lenders to raise loan-loss provisions and come up with realistic profit plans. That means profits won’t be growing, as the filings will show. -China keeps lending benchmark LPR steady for 4th straight month, in line with market – -China’s banking sector expected to dispose $490 bln of bad loans in 2020 – Xinhua – 3/ QUO VADIS, GREENBACK? The dollar, slipping to more than two year lows in recent days, looks out of favour thanks to negative inflation-adjusted yields, weaker macro-economic data and tensions between Washington and Beijing. The downward move has fueled familiar talk about the dollar’s decline as the world’s reserve currency. Investors are trying to gauge where next for the greenback. Intraday volatility has increased across the currency complex suggesting bearish positioning versus the dollar may be at extremes. And unlike July, when virtually all non-dollar currencies and precious metals gained on the dollar’s 4% fall, August has been a mixed bag. The yen and the Aussie have struggled. Even gold’s eye-watering rally is showing signs of exhaustion after hitting a record near $2,100 per ounce earlier this month. Throw in a U.S. Federal Reserve wary of pumping in more stimulus just yet, approaching U.S. elections and the greenback may find some fresh legs. -King dollar’s decline ripples across the globe. -U.S. dollar headed lower, in retreat against the euro 4/VALUE SIRENS Betting on a recovery of so-called value (read cheap) stocks has become a popular mainstream call among sell-side analysts as investors scramble to assess which bits of the market the rally could lift next. Value stocks generally lag in the first stages of a bounce-back but usually follow risk-on stocks upwards as the economic recovery unfolds. Now with hopes that a COVID-19 vaccine could be widely available in early 2021, overlooked undervalued stocks are becoming tempting targets for stock pickers. A rotation to value, targeting banks, autos and energy value stocks has already made tentative runs, but the decade long underperformance of that segment of the market means many won’t touch them with a barge pole. Looking at the outstanding performance of value stocks and big tech since the great financial crisis in general - and the COVID-19 market in particular - investors are wary of the value-trap. -LIVE MARKETS-Value sirens singing the blues -Capital exited stock markets as S&P hit new record - BofA 5/(BELA)RUSSIAN ROULETTE Belarus’s political crisis rumble on, dragging the European Union and the United States into another proxy standoff with Russia, the country’s main economic ally. Street protests over alleged vote rigging in President Alexander Lukashenko’s ‘landslide’ election win are set to continue in Minsk. With Lukashenko refusing to re-run the vote and starting a criminal case against the opposition, it’s not obvious how the tensions get resolved. For Moscow, Belarus is an important strategic buffer against NATO and the EU and Russia sells the country oil at below-market prices. But the relationship is testy and even Russia’s currency and bonds might now be affected by the situation, especially if sanctions come into play. Meanwhile the hospitalisation of Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny, the biggest thorn in the Kremlin’s side, will do little to shift unwanted attention away from Moscow, with Navalny’s allies alleging poisoning. -Pompeo says U.S. supports international probe of Belarus election -Belarusian protesters defy Lukashenko, EU announces sanctions -ANALYSIS-Putin bets on Lukashenko keeping power in Belarus for now - sources

BRUSSELS, February 28 (Sputnik) - The hearing of the case on international data privacy between the US Department of Justice (DOJ) and IT giant Microsoft, also known as the "Microsoft Ireland" case, is being held at the US Supreme Court on Tuesday.

The pending case was opened in 2013, when Microsoft challenged a warrant issued by US law enforcement officers to hand over emails of a target account, related to a probe into drug a trafficking case, that were stored on servers in Ireland.

Microsoft then argued that under US law, namely the 1986 Stored Communications Act, US-based companies could not be compelled to provide data held on servers outside the US, adding that the DOJ should take the relevant request to the Irish authorities​​​.

The US Department of Justice, in turn, contended that Microsoft, as a company operating in the United States, was required to respond to the law enforcement officers' request.

Despite the fact that the first round of hearings was won by the DOJ in 2014, the New York-based United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled in 2016 that the US government was unable to force Microsoft or any other company to hand over the emails that were held on servers outside the country.

In October 2017, the Supreme Court agreed to hear the appeal of US President Donald Trump's administration regarding the earlier ruling.

The Supreme Court is expected to issue the final verdict by the end of June.

OUTDATED LEGISLATION SHOULD BE ADDRESSED BY CONGRESS

Earlier on Tuesday, Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith said in a statement ahead of the hearing in court that, in his opinion, the US authorities could not be guided by laws written three decades ago, referring to the Stored Communications Act.

"We can’t rely on laws written three decades ago, before the internet as we know it was invented. Ultimately the courts – including the Supreme Court – can decide only whether the Department of Justice’s approach passes muster under current law," the statement read.

Smith underlined that despite the court's decision the majority of the work should be done by the US Congress, calling on the legislative body to adopt a law that would correspond to today's realities.

"But while attention today will focus on the Supreme Court, we believe the most important work should take place in the Capitol building across the street, by the U.S. Congress ... The courts are not able to write a new law. Under the U.S. Constitution, only Congress can do that, using its tools to craft a nuanced solution that balances all the competing concerns by enacting a statute for the 21st century," Smith stressed.

TOUGHER PRIVACY RIGHTS PROTECTION IN EUROPE

The European Union is closely monitoring the case, since similar problems exist across across the Atlantic. In May 2018, the European Union is expected to introduce its General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The new legislation will replace the EU Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC and harmonize data privacy laws across Europe to protect all EU citizens in their data privacy and reshape the way organizations across the region approach data privacy.

"There is a huge difference between what countries can decide in joint agreements on mutual legal assistance, and criminal law for individuals, where extraterritoriality cannot just be overruled like that. Microsoft is actually followed by the Irish government, when it refuses to deliver the emails that the US justice department requests. Can you imagine any dictatorship requesting tomorrow the same sort of access to its citizens’ data abroad?" a lawyer representing a big tech company said anonymously to Sputnik.

The GDPR will be tough for companies, organizations and individuals within Europe. In particular, the new privacy rights legislation is expected to extend its territorial competence to the organizations outside the European Union that provide goods and services to data subjects in the European Union.

In addition, the GDPR will require companies to make their requests for the processing of personal data consent more informative concrete and unambiguous.

EU SEEKS ACCESS TO PRIVATE DATA STORED OUTSIDE UNION

When it comes to access to private data in the interest of the EU authorities, EU member states still want to be a able to obtain information on servers across borders. That is why the European Commission is currently preparing relevant legislation.

"The EU executive wants law enforcement authorities to be able to access electronic evidence stored within the 28-nation bloc. This is known for a while and nothing new, there is a proposal in preparation on access to e-evidence for law enforcement (investigations and evidence within the EU). It was already discussed in the Justice council previously," Christian Wigand, a European Commission spokesman, told Sputnik.

The scope of the planned European legislation extends to data held elsewhere than in the European Union, which, according to experts, will be difficult to implement in reality.

Hawley's Latest Bill Puts Politics Ahead of Protecting Online Speech2020-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisR Street Institute: Sen. Hawley's Latest Bill Puts Politics Ahead of Protecting Online SpeechTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

The R Street Institute issued the following statement by Daisy Soderberg-Rivkin, resident fellow for technology policy:

Wednesday, Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) introduced the Limiting Section 230 Immunity to Good Samaritans Act (https://www.hawley.senate.gov/senator-hawley-announces-bill-empowering-americans-sue-big-tech-companies-acting-bad-faith). The bill restricts the applicability of legal liability protections for online service providers, currently found in Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The legislation would only apply to the largest platforms, defined as "edge providers" in the bill's text.

* * *

"This legislation is another in a long series of misguided attacks on Section 230. This time, it puts platforms on the receiving end of unending lawsuits for their moderation decisions, thereby disincentivizing any moderation at all."

"The bill uses strategically vague language to attack the perceived suppression of conservative speech on the largest social media platforms. Going well beyond reasonable community guidelines, this bill introduces undefined and indeterminate concepts like 'bad faith' and 'intentionally selective enforcement' that will raise questions in the courts and trigger waves of litigation for years to come. Uncertainty about the bill will furthermore drive platforms to avoid questions and litigation by degrading moderation to allow all types of vile or objectionable content on their service, or by over-moderating content -- even of a potentially conservative nature -- such that no posts left on the service could trigger any liability on the part of the company."

"Lawmakers concerned about protecting children online, preserving free speech and ensuring that social media remains open to all voices--not least of all conservatives--should instead rely on the free market, since the economy can support a virtually unlimited number of platforms, and neither they, nor anyone else, are required to use these services. The free market is vastly better than the heavy handed regulatory approach this bill proposes, which promises only to stifle speech."

[Category: Economics]

urn:contentItem:5V6V-4J61-J9XT-P1RC-00000-00Rubio Introduces Privacy Bill to Protect Consumers While Promoting Innovation2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRubio Introduces Privacy Bill to Protect Consumers While Promoting Innovation

Washington: Office of the Senator Marco Rubio has issued the following news release: U.S. Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) today introduced the American Data Dissemination (ADD) Act, legislation that would provide a national consumer data privacy law that protects both consumers and the innovative capabilities of the internet economy. By using the Privacy Act of 1974 as its framework, the bill provides overdue transparency and accountability from the tech industry while ensuring that small businesses and start-ups are still able to innovate and compete in the digital marketplace. A one-pager of the bill is available here.

“There has been a growing consensus that Congress must take action to address consumer data privacy,” Rubio said. “However, I believe that any efforts to address consumer privacy must also balance the need to protect the innovative capabilities of the digital economy that have enabled new entrants and small businesses to succeed in the marketplace. That is why I am introducing the American Data Dissemination Act, which will protect small businesses and startups while ensuring that consumers are provided with overdue rights and protections. It is critical that we do not create a regulatory environment that entrenches big tech corporations. Congress must act, but it is even more important that Congress act responsibly to create a transparent, digital environment that maximizes consumer welfare over corporate welfare.” Specifically, the ADD Act would do the following: Not later than 180 days after enactment of the ADD Act, the FTC is required to submit detailed recommendations for privacy requirements that Congress can impose on covered providers. These requirements would be substantially similar to the requirements applicable to agencies under the Privacy Act of 1974. Not earlier than one year after the date on which the Commission has submitted detailed recommendations (18 months after enactment), the FTC will publish and submit to the appropriate committees of Congress proposed regulations to impose privacy requirements on covered providers that are substantially similar to the requirements applicable to agencies under the Privacy Act of 1974. To ensure Congress acts in a timely manner, if the Congress fails to enact a law based on the recommendations provided by the date that is two years after enactment of this bill, the FTC would promulgate a final rule, not later than 27 months after the date of enactment to impose privacy requirements based on the narrow, congressionally mandated course of action created through this bill.

urn:contentItem:5V6X-C0D1-DYTH-G20B-00000-00RUBIO INTRODUCES PRIVACY BILL TO PROTECT CONSUMERS WHILE PROMOTING INNOVATION2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRUBIO INTRODUCES PRIVACY BILL TO PROTECT CONSUMERS WHILE PROMOTING INNOVATIONStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, D.C.

The following information was released by Florida Senator Marco Rubio:

U.S. Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) today introduced the American Data Dissemination (ADD) Act, legislation that would provide a national consumer data privacy law that protects both consumers and the innovative capabilities of the internet economy. By using the Privacy Act of 1974 as its framework, the bill provides overdue transparency and accountability from the tech industry while ensuring that small businesses and start-ups are still able to innovate and compete in the digital marketplace. A one-pager of the bill is available here.

"There has been a growing consensus that Congress must take action to address consumer data privacy," Rubio said. "However, I believe that any efforts to address consumer privacy must also balance the need to protect the innovative capabilities of the digital economy that have enabled new entrants and small businesses to succeed in the marketplace. That is why I am introducing the American Data Dissemination Act, which will protect small businesses and startups while ensuring that consumers are provided with overdue rights and protections. It is critical that we do not create a regulatory environment that entrenches big tech corporations. Congress must act, but it is even more important that Congress act responsibly to create a transparent, digital environment that maximizes consumer welfare over corporate welfare."

Specifically, the ADD Act would do the following:

Not later than 180 days after enactment of the ADD Act, the FTC is required to submit detailed recommendations for privacy requirements that Congress can impose on covered providers. These requirements would be substantially similar to the requirements applicable to agencies under the Privacy Act of 1974.

Not earlier than one year after the date on which the Commission has submitted detailed recommendations (18 months after enactment), the FTC will publish and submit to the appropriate committees of Congress proposed regulations to impose privacy requirements on covered providers that are substantially similar to the requirements applicable to agencies under the Privacy Act of 1974.

To ensure Congress acts in a timely manner, if the Congress fails to enact a law based on the recommendations provided by the date that is two years after enactment of this bill, the FTC would promulgate a final rule, not later than 27 months after the date of enactment to impose privacy requirements based on the narrow, congressionally mandated course of action created through this bill.

Earlier today, Rubio penned an op-ed addressing the need for Congress to address consumer data privacy.

urn:contentItem:5PK3-FRB1-F15W-H0WX-00000-00RUCHIR SHARMA, CHIEF GLOBAL STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING THE ECONOMY AND POLITICS2017-09-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:21ZLexisNexisRUCHIR SHARMA, CHIEF GLOBAL STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING THE ECONOMY AND POLITICS

September 25, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

RUCHIR SHARMA, CHIEF GLOBAL STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT,

FERRO: Joining us now around the table in New York is Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management.

He is the Chief Global Strategist and Head of Emerging Markets. His book, "The Rise and Fall of Nations: Forces of Change in the Post- Crisis World" is available now in Paperback. Ruchir, great to have you with us on the program.

SHARMA: Good to be back.

FERRO: Let's start in your book, you talked about the rhythm of the jungle and identifying the difference between noise and signal and where a tree might fall, et cetera.

The weekend with the president of the United States, where's the noise and where's the signal, Ruchir?

SHARMA: Well, I think, there's a lot of noise across the world because there's so many like elections also which took this weekend, right?

You know, starting from New Zealand, Germany, France, et cetera. And then, look back here, even at the United States in terms of the approval ratings.

And here's the sort of takeaway that I have in terms of what's happening in the world today.

One, it is extremely difficult to be an incumbent or a politician in power today.

In fact, we have data going back a few years and then our database, basically, shows that never before have leaders across the world being this unpopular.

So we looked at the approval ratings of leaders across the world here in democracies in particular, where we can rely on the data.

And we find that the approval ratings of incumbents in power today is of the lowest level since we've started keeping the data.

It was down about 20 percent each points compared to a decade ago, the average of approval ratings.

So whether it's -- call it over Trump here or even in the places where the leaders are winning the election bids.

In places like Germany, they're coming back with much reviews majority.

So that is what I think as an anti-incumbent surge across the world and the honeymoon effect is getting shorter and shorter every day with leaders that are losing their popularity very rapidly.

I mean, I'm pretty stunned by what's happening in France and Brazil with Macron's sort of popularity has diminished so quickly after just two to four months in power.

And so, I think, there's been this -- like German election, Angela Merkel sort of, you know, much reviews majority victory rather in this election.

It's just so difficult for an incumbent to go on today. And remember, the Germany possibly has the best economic fundamentals of any developed countries, you know.

We looked at the per capita, income growth of all developed countries, Germany ranked as number one, Angela Merkel over the last decade. And yet, she's facing enough pressures from the right -- within the country.

FERRO: You have described the journey then. What's the destination here? What's the end game?

SHARMA: Well, I think, that -- I mean, in terms of maybe anti- incumbent is sort of constant journey in terms of what's going on that, you know, when in doubt, throw the bums out.

I think that is the defining mantra of this era. And, I think, that's what we should look at in terms of this constant journey, incumbent leaders just keep, you know, keep getting thrown out.

And Merkel has done really well by staying in power, but what worries me about Merkel is the fact that the longer the leader stays in power, the more difficult it is for the leader to remain popular.

I mean, that even in Germany, the person who stayed in power for even longer before her was Helmut Kohl, right?

But look at her, you know, like in terms of how he was treated after 16 years in power.

So it's just sort of very difficult time to be in power in this rather challenging global environment.

STEEL: I am really interested though in a relationship between businesses and leaders of a country whether or not it's the German automakers and now, what Merkel has to do to deal with the coalition here in the U.S.

You had Trump really attacking the NFL, I feel like if NFL was a stock six months ago, it would have been tanking but today, maybe not. What's the relationship there?

SHARMA: No, I think, it's bound to be a bit more confrontational because, you know, I think that it's easy picking for many politicians who basically, you know, go after businesses or go after, you know, in people who are in power.

And, I think, that this is what to means like one of the biggest risk as global bull market as well, which is that if you look at the regulatory some building against some of the tech companies now.

You know, like that I think is one of the biggest sort of threats to this bull market because the leadership there has been all about tech.

So I do feel that this is a bigger risk which is taking place. But, of course, in Germany's case what's a lot interesting now that we have discussed a lot actually about the rise of the AfD and the populous, right?

But it's also interesting that a very (INAUDIBLE) within this party out there also did rather well, getting more than 10 percent of the work.

They've been out there like in Germany. So, I think that it's a very complicated scenario out there, but generally, I think the people across the world are very willing to turn against the establishment at the slightest excuse.

And Merkel has been very good at playing those games in terms of how do you sort of, you know, just about move at the right minute to try and (INAUDIBLE) the opposition. But even she's finding it increasingly difficult to do so.

WESTIN: If this anti-incumbent biased is universal around the world, it can't be a coincidence.

There must be some common factor or factors that driving it. Is that a matter of growing income and wealth and equality which causes people to be dissatisfied?

Is that a matter of technological change, globalization? What are the factors you see that's driving that anti-incumbent biased?

SHARMA: (INAUDIBLE) constant, right? In terms of rising income equality has to be one, everywhere you go, people speak about that as being a big issue.

But the fact that just economic growth is just so low everywhere, I think that also has to be a factor, it's just less of the (INAUDIBLE) to be sort of given.

And then I wonder if there's a media effect as well which is that it's source (INAUDIBLE) contagious, it spread so quickly in terms of the people the way they go after the establishment --

FERRO: (INAUDIBLE) Ruchir, join in, why not.

SHARMA: No, but at the margin, but I think that I'm really surprise to see as to how quickly the honeymoon of leaders comes to an end, you know, like 20 years ago, we've had a much longer honeymoon period.

And Macron in terms of the way he's been skewered by the French media in the last three months, it's something which tells you that, "Listen, it's not even sort of (INAUDIBLE) yet and given such a back clash."

Well, I think that you are basically correct that the origins of this anti-incumbent (INAUDIBLE) which is ripping the world today is basically economic in nature and income equality has to be on the big issues behind us.

STEEL: Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management, you'll be sticking with us, much more conversation on that throughout the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WESTIN: Still with us is Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management. So, Ruchir, it seems like with the notable Central Bank of England, the central bank seemingly heading more or less in the same direction which is either backing off of the easing or actually tightening some. Is that where they should be headed?

SHARMA: Yes, I think so. Because, I think that, you know, like the big internal debate that is possibly happening at many central banks and which -- about which -- we may -- I'm not hearing that much publicly but it's showing up in the minutes.

And on that sort of TVs is the fact that they need to pay much more attention to financial stability, that the mandate of central banks so far has broadly mean inflation targeting.

And so over the last few years, you've seen this attitude that inflation is under control they can keep providing lots of stimulus and run a very easy monitory policy.

But now, I think, there is an increase recognition that as much as risk to the economy from asset prices sort of going up too high rather than just consuming prices going up too high.

And there's one step to stick out here which I keep sort of reminding people off the shore, how much the world has changed.

We should have 30 years ago exactly at this -- I mean, around this time, we have the 1987 stock market crash, where you have the massive decline in one day.

But the real economy really did not suffer much for it, right? But today, that is unlikely to happen and here's why.

The size of the financial economy today is 3-1/2 times the size of the underlying real economy. 30 years ago, they were nearly the same.

Today, the 3-1/2 times larger, so that's my entire shoe here which is that now the tail wags the dog and if you look at every single major recession that's taking place in the world over the last 20 to 30 years starting with Japan in the 1990s, East Asia in the late 1990s followed by the thick bubble going burst in the early 2000s.

And then, of course, the 2007-2008 global financial crisis, each one was really preceded by financial instability which is massive asset price inflation followed by asset price bust, and that having to see these consequences for the economy.

WESTIN: When there's so much in the central banks, the western central banks have done something as financial stability by just increasing reserve requirements under regulatory issues in the banks.

What you're talking about as you say is bubbles bursting, what is the history, the track record that central banks in being able to take some of the air out of those bubbles without going too far?

SHARMA: Well, they haven't tried that much so far because the sort of -- the learning philosophy which is what sort of Greenspan led with was the fact that we can't support bubbles, it'll be much better at cleaning up the mess.

So we should (INAUDIBLE) this very (INAUDIBLE) central banks reaction which should have been bubbles are so forming, central banks really passive about it.

But the moment they burst, they rush out with the entire (INAUDIBLE) to try and sort of get the economies to go again.

So, therefore, we have seen this massive increase, I think, in the financial economy relative to the underlying economy.

So I think that for me, is an outdated concept. And central banking evolves. I mean, remember that in the 1970s the central banks never really focused that much with even inflation.

Inflation targeting only came as a formal mandate for the Fed in 1977. So central bank -- central bank thinking evolves.

And, I think, that we have, again, on that stage with central bank thinking needs to evolve out here.

STEEL: So from our perspective it seemed like fiscal stimulus is like your worst-case scenario?

SHARMA: Well, in a way, because I think that we spoke -- we lead this program that we're talking about Trump sort of the tax cut plan, which is fine.

I mean, he wants to reform the tax code, everyone is (INAUDIBLE) but here's the problem that, you know, which I think that it need to really (INAUDIBLE)

At this stage often, economic cycle, the United States has never run such a large fiscal deficit as it is currently doing.

Remember, what the classic sort of concept used to be which is that you run off to school (INAUDIBLE) in good times and you spend it in bad times.

(CROSSTALK)

SHARMA: Exactly. But it appears that you quaint, but I think that you need to sort of keep that in mind that the fiscal deficit today in the United States is very large, at this stage of the economic cycle, it's never been this large.

And we just think about what will we do the next time we have an economic downturn. And we need to reserve some bullet for that.

I think that that is something we should not properly sort of understood or amplified enough in this rush to do something to pass that tax reform.

FERRO: (INAUDIBLE) kind of lose the book when the good times come.

WESTIN: That's absolutely right.

FERRO: And they stayed that one page which just means stimulus, stimulus --

SHARMA: Stimulus, stimulus, stimulus, absolutely.

FERRO: I do wonder about how you define good times? Are these good times?

SHARMA: Well, in terms of the fact that there are good times because of what we experienced in postwar history, where we're used to global economic growth being much higher.

But some of us have argued that the reason that global economic growth is much lower today has to do with some factor which is outside our control and demographics.

To me, the single most important reason why the global economy truly is not growing as rapidly as it was for much of postwar history is because the demographics have changed.

Which is the world's population growth we have today is a lot lower. Germany is a classic example of that which in fact next decade Germany's labor force is expected to shrink every single year by hundreds of thousands.

And so an answer to that could have been immigration but that's increasingly off the table given what's that going to the social fabric.

So -- but, I do feel the fact that the global economy today is growing about as fast as it possibly can.

This is the trend growth rates for the global economy now and to sort of think that this economy required a stimulus is a bit of a misguided step.

FERRO: So with the demographics in to the political story and where we go in here. Are we in a race for the bottom and what I mean by that if you happen an older generation and you have a demographics, so instead of demographics in the western world that increasingly get older that of a particular way, are they set to continue voting that way?

And therefore, does it just make the problem greater and greater until ultimately, Ruchir, they die. Is that where it's going?

SHARMA: I don't quite thought, you know, like that far out in terms of what this (INAUDIBLE) circle that you're outlining out here sort of gets too.

But I do feel that, you know, that this angst is likely to continue which is in fact that, you know, this whole thing that whoever is in power, the angst is just against whoever that, you know, like people are in power with the results not so good.

And remember the fact that they have a big anchoring biased which are the fact that the global economy today is still growing at the fastest pace that it has grown if you look at it from multi-century standpoint.

But because they're so used to the very rapid growth that they've got in the 1980s and 1990s, and last decade, and we think that the global economy is not doing that well.

So lot of anchoring biased is here in how we view the global economy and that's something which shapes in to the political discourse as well.

WESTIN: Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management will be staying with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

STEEL: And still with us is Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management. That echoes what you're talking about before that if you end up having a regulatory over hang on a big tech name, thus significantly impact the outperform of the bull market.

SHARMA: Yes, it does. I think that, you know, for next year, there are two or three risk with this bull market. I mean, apart from the fact that it is getting oil.

But we know that oil (INAUDIBLE) is not enough to sort of kill the bull market.

But what could the catalyst be, I think, it's worth thinking about. So the one -- the one we spoke about the regulatory sort of overhang, you know, and those forces are building you can see sentiment turning towards sort of big tech.

And this argument that there's increase concentration of power among a few companies and each sector of the United States is leading to a problem and this is a global phenomenon, by the way.

So that's there. But the second one is quite basic which is that every single bull market in U.S. has really has been killed by the Fed as people say.

I think that the thing sort of risk is building up for next year which is the QE as we have called it, and now turning in to QT next year which is like it really becomes quantitative tightening.

STEEL: Quantitative tightening.

SHARMA: I think that the risk from that are greatly understated which is that you have this massive expansion and multiples and cause by liquidity. And then liquidity begins to turn, what that leads to is possibly being underestimated.

And it's changing the margin, remember that these people speak about how the central bank balance sheet across the world will keep increasing, you know, with ECB and Bank of Japan still doing some buying all bid, reduce space.

Markets really function at the second level relatively in terms of rate of change. And that's beginning to return next year quite significantly.

STEEL: Where do you see that stuff?

SHARMA: In terms of --

STEEL: In the market like where are you going to see that? Because if the Fed has had its way, you're going to see no volatility in the treasury markets and it's really smooth and these supplies is going to come out to be really nice and smooth. Where do you look for that crack?

SHARMA: No, in terms of the fact that like I said that the -- that if they're in a preset course, right? And the underlying economy is still doing OK.

I think that by about the second quarter of next year this really, globally, begins will turn into quantitative tightening.

And as I said that markets don't function in a very linear way that there'll be sort of (INAUDIBLE) about it, and then all of a sudden they'll begin worrying about it and then they'll be no in to it.

So I think that these are sort of very binary ships which happened in markets and I think that the risk is building up next year as you begin to get quantitative tightening across central banks, that's going to happen.

And the other three which we haven't spoken about is China, right? The fact is that in China to the central bank there is -- and the authority if they push the party congress, I think, are likely to step up.

Some of their monetary tightening and deleveraging which is what it kept on hold because they want nothing to go wrong until the party congress got out of the way in mid October.

FERRO: Ruchir Sharma it's great to have you with us. Morgan Stanley Investment Management, of course, Chief Strategist is sticking with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FERRO: Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management still with us. Ruchir, we spend a little bit of time talking about technology and the regular push back.

What we're seeing across geographies is an approach from Europe really around the tax issues getting this big technology companies to pay more tax.

Here in the United States it seems to be a more ethical issue the way they control the content that is on various platforms.

What do you think is ultimately going to be the biggest issue for these big companies? The European approach or the U.S. approach as it evolves?

SHARMA: Well, I think, that the U.S. approach is the bigger risk here which sort of the sentiment begins to turn in to the regulatory stuff, you know, going after this big companies and these parties has already been drawn as, you know, in the -- in the -- like in the media about the fact that data is the new oil and some of the big sort of companies like Standard Oil have broken down, we need to do something with these companies.

So I think that they are there yet, I mean, if -- you know, I think that if you speak to people back in California and stuff all the people in government, I don't think that they are there yet which is they sort of say that (INAUDIBLE) break down.

But sentiment is beginning to turn and I think that the other thing we haven't spoken about is that it's quite remarkable that we find that in China there's much left of our commodity of this even though if you look at the top 10 companies in the world today, two of them are from China now in terms of largest in the world.

So I think that it's important to keep an eye out there that how are they sort of dealing with it.

I think that (INAUDIBLE) attitude is more that these companies are such big employment created at the time when the economy is sort of transitioning from an old to a new economy that they haven't seen much conversation there.

But that's something also they haven't seen some chatter, you know, we sort of -- there was a bit of sort of little panic a couple of months ago when one of the party official described all this online gaming as electronic heroine out there.

So I think it's -- that this global sentiment is turning but I'm not sort of looking for anything dramatic to happen just now and as typically it happens it's after we have some crisis that's when the regulatory risk goes up the walls. Currently, it's more chatter.

FERRO: China has in many control, obviously, some of that social media platform. And they certainly don't allow the likes of Facebook to come in to the country the way Facebook would like to be in to the country.

Are we going to see a model based on China here in the United States, is that where is this going where we banned the use of Winnie the Pooh on the platform --

SHARMA: No, I don't believe so.

FERRO: -- (INAUDIBLE) sensitivities towards a cartoon?

SHARMA: No, I don't think so. I mean, you know, in terms of -- I mean, I don't think that we are anywhere close to that. But I think that, you know, at the Fed that it's important to keep in mind because as we're speaking with my book earlier.

And I remember, you know, they're writing a chapter on the good and bad billionaire, the sign of income equality and sort of saying that the billionaire's coming out the tech industry should be classified.

And the good billionaires because they're inspirational, they seemed to be non -- sort of nonhereditary and sort of positive consumer effect coming from them.

For me, it's like watching that sentiment that when you begin to classify them as bad billionaires, but I don't think we are there yet.

It's -- the sentiment is still largely positive, although it's building at a risk and worth keeping in mind.

WESTIN: There are two very different questions here. Are you bad as a company, misbehaving, and we have seen some evidenced of that as well with Uber and things?

Another one is you may be very good but you are acquiring a monopoly interest with restricted communications of information.

And the history in this country traditionally when that happens, the government figured out -- it figures out some way to regulate, that was the FCC with local broadcasters.

It was -- it was a government regulation of the telephone lines, it happens invariably and particularly that's true, Ruchir, when it starts to affect political speech, when it affects candidates in their campaigns.

SHARMA: Very true, but I think that this is a universal problem. It's not just over the tech industry, if you locate it across the board, every single, like almost every industry located in the United States has seen increase concentration, which is that if you look at the shares of the top three companies, it's gone up in almost, I think, the exact numbers of 80 percent of all industries.

It sounds very high number of that, so this is more a symptom of a superstar economy of sort of, you know, increase concentration and yet tech is at the leading edge of this because this is where the bull is taking place. But this is the much wider problem of increase monopoly power and increase concentration across industries.

WESTIN: Absolutely right. But this is not just tech, this is tech as it applies to content, our information, our opinions. That is particularly a sensitive subject with the government around the world including the United States.

SHARMA: Yes, I think -- but, you know, like look for some of the TVs here which show that are our people in (INAUDIBLE) talking that language and I think that so far I'm not hearing that.

So it's a -- it's a building risk but I don't see it something which is not going to happen tomorrow in terms of that this is going to sort of unravel.

It's going back to basics in terms of what's going to end this bull market, we're all looking for those factors now given that there's so much complacency out there such low volatility and take to the leading edge of this bull market.

But I still see the bigger risk comes from things like valuations compressing given them out instead of easy money which is being outdate and that's being withdrawn gradually overtime. And the regulatory risk is definitely something which I would put as a factor out there.

But I think that those typically come after you have a crisis not before you have a downturn.

STEEL: Well, fair point. But let's stay on tech and take a look at Apple speaking with their clients and all the three major averages this morning down by about six percent in the last four days.

Straight four days down shedding nearly 50 billion in market cap. Mike Olson has an overweight rating on the stock and boosting his price target on Friday to 1.96 from 1.90.

And Mike joins us on the phone from Minneapolis. Mike, why does stock decline over the last four days and why did you upgrade your price target?

OLSON (via telephone): Well, obviously, with the later launch of the iPhone X Apple has caused some degree of near term negative impact for the iPhone 8.

And we still think that this is going to be a long-term positive in the sense of rising ASPs in the next shift towards more iPhone X buyers.

So, I guess, in other words I would just say there are a lot of costumers that would probably wait for iPhone X.

As a result, it could look as though the launch is up to a slow started, it is looking as though that's the case when in reality it's probably just a sign of next shift to higher end iPhones.

STEEL: Well, fair point, so if you say, "OK, you're not going to buy the 8 because you're going to wait for the X." OK, but then you have that report from DigiTimes today saying that actually they're asking the suppliers to cut back on their iPhone X components because they kind of want to see how the launch goes. How do you factor that in?

OLSON: Well, I think that's typical Apple, their strategy has been maintained very tight inventory in the channel, they're not going to bail out a ton of extra iPhone X inventory in advance of knowing exactly how it's going to sell.

And I think in particular in the past, we've actually seen them come in to this launches with low inventory just to kind of maintain a buzz or some hyper on the launch.

So I think this is not a typical for Apple's, you know, inventory management practices.

WESTIN: So, Mike, inventory you mentioned have always sounds like it's a good idea. But certainly Apple is not very happy with the response they ate so far because that's what the reports are.

And I thought maybe they take a hit on the 8 so they could really get the X up, but now, we're told they're going to actually shift fewer Xs from the time being. Isn't that raising some questions about how confident they are on their launch?

OLSON: It could be, but we'll have to see if this, you know, I would put this in the category of kind of chatter out of Asia. At this point, we'll have to see to what degree this is really results in concerning around iPhone X demand weakness.

If again, I think, it's more related to tightness in the channel line to maintain that more than any sort of concern around in demand weakness.

I think iPhone 8 weakness is real, but that should really only be a risk for the September quarter.

So we've actually moved about 500,000 iPhones out of our September quarter estimate and in to the December and March quarter as a result for that.

FERRO: Mike Olson, appreciate your time, sir. Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray, thank you. And Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley will be staying with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

STEEL: And still with us Ruchir Sharma of Morgan Stanley Investment Management. Ruchir, I love what Alex is saying about how Europe is a crisis management institution.

There was rhetoric that for the first time Merkel gets to govern without a crisis. What is the next crisis for Europe as you see it?

SHARMA: Well, I think it's something with a flag which is like Italy in terms of what happens to those elections because that's clearly where the anti-European sentiment is the most.

It's clearly where the economic growth has been so weak in terms of the last few years. So that's -- that has to be something on the -- on the horizon.

But, you know, like (INAUDIBLE) discussion about Angela Merkel in terms of the fact that he accepting that she's a remarkable leader.

But I think that really what sort of underestimate that she is a more brilliant politician than she is a leader of the free world so to speak, which are the fact that just look at the way in the last few years she's able to change her position as (INAUDIBLE)

It's not as if she's sticking with some great principle, she's not (INAUDIBLE) type of leader with some very strong principles, and wants to lead the world in a particular direction.

She's more about the fact that a very adjoin politician which is that how do you act just in time to take the edge of the opposition and keep sort of moving ahead.

Now, of course, you can argue that's a very good stance to take, it's very non-ideological but she's not the classical leader and like the way that we think about it that about taking the people with her.

She's more like sort of fitting behind, watching about which way the wind is blowing and be able to position her way in that direction.

So my sense is that after this election unless she really change her attack, it just starts thinking about her legacy and the fact that this is her last term.

But if she really keeps thinking about her popularity which is how she is govern for the last few years, my feeling is this entire project of euro of sort of bringing Germany and France together. She's not going to read this election result as a sort of an endorsement of that.

So I think that is something which is we're keeping in mind that her governing principle is more about just moving in time to be at the right position rather than sort of having a very strong ideological commitment to anything from Europe to immigration.

WESTIN: She's been very depth at it so far. I think it's fair to say. So it's not just Angela Merkel in Germany we're focused on. It's also a big week ahead for the world central banks and the legislative agenda here in the United States

Tomorrow, Fed Chair Janet Yellen will speak. On Wednesday, President Trump is set to give a former tax reform outline and a healthcare vote is expected later in the week in congress.

We'll also be hearing from Bank of England Governor Mark Carney on Thursday. Joining us now from Cleveland is Bloomberg's Michael McKee.

So, Mike, that's a lot to cover. I want you to start with Janet Yellen, you're going to be listening to her.

MCKEE: Janet Yellen will be speaking her in Cleveland before the National Association for Business Economics. A lot of people want to know what the Fed thinks is going to drive inflation higher.

There's a general feeling here that it is going to happen and people are not abandoning Yellen and the idea of the Phillips curve that is unemployment goes down, inflation goes up.

But they're wondering what's happened why is it taking so long. We heard from Bill Dudley this morning probably her closest ally on the Fed saying, "It's going to start going up reasonably soon." But we're still waiting.

WESTIN: So as we wait, to what extent are they waiting for congress and the president and tax reform, are they just basically put that in their minds at this point?

MCKEE: You know, that's a very good question because the NABE surveyed its members, these are the economists who worked for all the biggest companies in America.

They surveyed their members and they found some optimism about growth of the future but allowed that predicated on the idea of tax reform and infrastructure reform.

Without that we sort of thread water. Here's Ken Simonson, he's the survey director the Head of The Associated General Contractors of America. Here's what he had to say about that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEN SIMONSON, HEAD, ASSOCIATED GENERAL CONTRACTORS OF AMERICA: I would stay cautious increase that businesses do believe the economy will keep expanding. These forecasters think that we'll see pretty steady gross domestic product growth, real GDP that is digested for inflation for little over two percent which is pretty much the range we're getting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKEE: So unless we can get something, guys, the NABE economist think we're stuck in this two percent range.

STEEL: So what kind of thread is Janet Yellen need to -- need to sew here particularly when we don't even know who's sitting in the Fed Chair in February sort of setting stuff up for rate hikes but then also not getting too hawkish at the same time?

MCKEE: Yes, that's basically, all she can do at this point is emphasize the fact that the Fed wants a little more room, a little more ability to operate if something bad should happen to the economy which is not the expectation here.

Dudley said this morning the chances of recession in the future very small, in the near future very small.

But the focus is really on fiscal and that's where Donald Trump and the tax reform plan come in.

And whether or not, once the details are released, anybody believes that it's actually going to happen anytime soon.

The folks here think by the end of 2018 but, of course, so the way Washington works isn't necessarily the way things work here in Cleveland.

FERRO: Ruchir, let's wrap things up the way we started noise versus signal, how helpful does that speak?

SHARMA: Well, I think that it's, obviously, like important to watch but I like the way that sort of economists keep saying that, you know, the relative chances of the recession in the near future and stuff.

I mean, as we have done work on this, how many recessions have economists been able to predict and post on his feet, exactly zero.

So, I think that let's sort of (INAUDIBLE) back about, you know, when people say that, "Well, it's policy makers on stuff about no recession, et cetera, et cetera." That's just the way of life.

The fact that next year this is going to be second longest economic expansion in history, just means we need to be more on the alert about work and under (INAUDIBLE)

FERRO: Ruchir Sharma, great to have you with us throughout the hour of Morgan Stanley Investment Management. And, of course, to Bloomberg's Michael Mckee busy over the week full of Federal Reserve speakers from New York.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
